—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer inform the House of the significance of the March 1992 balance of payments figure released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. The statistician revealed today that the monthly current account deficit was $938m, which was a little higher than market expectations, but one which took the nine-month figure to March 1992 to a little over $9 billion, which is, of course, well within the Budget time forecast of $14 billion for 1991-92.

PARA.TAB: The figures also mean that the merchandise trade balance has been in surplus continuously since December 1990, and the surplus has averaged nearly $400m a month since that time. The March 1992 surplus of $428m is consistent with that trend. Indeed, the ABS figures indicate that there was a surplus of $231m in the balance of goods and services, seasonally adjusted, and this makes the twelfth such surplus in the last 15 months.

The ABS figures are consistent with the view that there has been a structural shift towards exports in the Australian economy. This shift has been evident since the Labor Government came to power, and has been especially clear since 1989. It is perhaps worth recalling that in 1981 Australia's exports accounted for just 11 per cent of GDP, whereas in 1991, just 10 years later, they accounted for 19 per cent. Ten years ago exports accounted for 11 per cent of GDP; now they account for 19 per cent, close to double the 1981 figure. They represent a much bigger part of a much larger GDP.

This, I think, indicates that this has been the decade of very strong export growth in Australia. It was always an ambition of the Government when it came to power in 1983 to put more emphasis on exports from Australia, an issue which had been basically neglected by our opponents for a very long time. We have been the Party which has put exports back into the equation of the Australian economy. It is not just a question of improving the prospects of our traditional exports from our farms and our mines but, more particularly, getting our manufacturing sector and our services sector in a state where they can compete effectively and successfully with the rest of the world.

This trend, which has been revealed once again in these monthly figures is, I think, something which all Australians are entitled to be pleased about. This is not just a question of the fortuitous sale of some primary commodities, some mineral commodities, it is very much a measure of the way in which Australians are working. Men and women in Australia are working in such a way that the product of their labour is now more competitive, of a higher quality, better priced and, therefore, capable of achieving larger export markets in the rest of the world. This is the kind of way in which the Australian economy has been changing in the last 10 years and I think it will continue to change in that very beneficial direction in the future.

The other point to bear in mind—we hear this time and time again—is that, whenever the question of improved export performance is mentioned, the Opposition simply says, `Oh, this is just a function of the recession'. It is not. This has been a trend which has occurred over the last 10 years regardless of whether the economy was growing fast or slowly. It is evidence of a structural change that has happened in the Australian economy, one which we should be proud of, not one that should be denigrated, as it is so frequently by those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, is about child-care. Has the Government given consideration to the use of tax expenditures to fund child-care for Australian families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to thank the honourable member for Forde for her work on the development of the national accreditation policy and her work in child-care. In the past, the Government has looked at tax expenditures in relation to child-care through rebates and deductions. We have rejected them because they have failed the basic tests of fairness. Tax rebates or deductions, as I think most people realise, provide most assistance to families on the highest incomes. Families whose incomes are too low to pay tax obviously get no benefit at all from such concessions. A tax rebate or deduction is of no value to a family if it cannot find a child-care place. So the Government's national child-care strategy is focused on the two aims of affordability and supply.

PARA.TAB: There are now 130,000 families being assisted with fee relief. The number of families getting fee relief has more than doubled in the last two years. There are now 178,000 funded child-care places. We have more than trebled the number since 1983. We will have 250,000 funded child-care places by 1995-96. Rebates, of course, do not build child-care centres. These issues were well and truly understood by Australian families at the last election. That is why they rejected the Opposition's policy of tax rebates. They saw it as unfair because it gave help to those who perhaps needed it the least. Last year we thought that the message had, in fact, finally got through to the Opposition. I was very pleased that in June last year the Opposition spokesperson on child-care, Senator Alston, went as far as to endorse the Government's fee relief system and child-care strategy. On ABC radio here in Canberra, about the Government's strategy, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: It is income tested. . . It is fairly generous . . . and it seems to me that approach, in terms of where you cut out the assistance, is probably not too far wide of the mark.
He went on to say about child-care fee relief:
We've got to look more seriously at whether we think that is more appropriate than our approach, the Opposition's approach.

I think it is fair to say that I felt very grateful to Senator Alston because he finally realised the strength of the Government's position. So I was very surprised to see clearly stated in the Sydney Morning Herald today that the Opposition would now introduce tax rebates for child-care. Back in June when Senator Alston described the Government's child-care policy as fair, generous and not too wide of the mark, he also had a fair bit to say about tax rebates. I would like those comments recorded. He said:
My preference would be to target assistance to lower income earning groups.
He went on to say:
I am not able to say why I would think you would provide child-care rebates or child-care assistance across-the-board.

He was obviously not able to say why the Opposition would advocate that because it is really as indefensible as the GST is on child-care because it targets people on the lowest incomes to pay the most. So I presume that here we have another example of `Flexiback'. Not only was Senator Alston admitting that the Opposition got it wrong at the last election and now was about providing a child-care system which met the test of fairness but also it is now clear that he is well and truly in conflict with the current policy of his Leader, creating further divisions within the Opposition. Last week it was tariffs; this week it is child-care.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

PARA.TAB: The rejections of the Government's One Nation program by the OECD as evidenced by its considerably lower growth forecasts for the Australian economy, a higher unemployment forecast and its urgent call for more vigorous micro-economic reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very appropriate to quote the Canberra Times editorial today on the OECD survey of Australia for 1991-92, which starts by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Last week's report by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development on the Australian economy is a distressing and depressing catalogue of Australia's missed economic opportunities in the last decade.

The last decade being, of course, the time under which this Government has been administered by the Australian Labor Party. It is particularly depressing and particularly distressing, as this report comes from the OECD.

PARA.TAB: Australia is a fee paying member of the OECD. The OECD gives the Federal Government the chance to influence any final reports. So the Government actually gets a say in the final drafting of the reports, which in most cases are more favourable or, shall we say, ensure that the message is put in subtle terms. In other words, they pull their punches, if you like, in the drafting of these reports. So when the reports come out critical, even on the face of them, they are a damning indictment of the Government of the day.

On this occasion, the OECD really carpeted the Government's economic management in a most blunt way. Virtually no stone has been left unturned. Whilst there are all sorts of the usual qualifications that one gets from the OECD—one can be sure that Federal Treasury officers have been writing in bits and pieces throughout the report to try to tone it down—it makes compelling reading for anybody interested in the future management of this economy.

I take the opportunity to commend those Treasury officers who, to the extent that they did, let the truth shine through this report, as it has, in such crystal clear terms. I have no doubt that to some extent it reflects the fact that Treasury itself is very concerned that this Government loves to hide the truth from the Australian people about the extent of our problems. We have the Budget deficit blowing out and, of course, as most Australians know, Australia's worst recession in 60 years rolls on inexorably.

This report card from the OECD is very critical. In it, Australia fails virtually every subject. The OECD says we are going to have to go back and do the subjects again. Perhaps worst of all, the OECD says that in this case Australia has failed to try hard enough to correct the problems of the last 10, 15, 20 or more years. We have not attempted to keep up with the rest of the class; Australia has fallen behind the rest of the world.

In a report where there is a mark of five out of 25, I know the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) will get up and spend all of his time telling us how good the five marks are. In that sense it is balanced; there are some things where the Government is entitled to some credit. But when reading this report, one could not help come to the conclusion that this Government's economic policies have been an absolute failure. I suppose one does not need to be an economist to know that. In this country we have net foreign liabilities of nearly $200 billion and our net debt is about $145 billion. Do not get up and blame it on the last Government, because when this Government came into office this country's debt was about $23 billion. It has gone from $23 billion to $145 billion. And, of course, the number of unemployed is now around a million people.

A quick glance at this report card reveals over 20 points where Australia has not done well. Point No. 1, on page 9, essentially says that high interest rates have brought on the recession and have thereby lowered inflation—a point on which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was attacking me last week, the very day that the report came out. I had said, `Look, you always get low inflation in a recession'. He attacked me for that during Question Time and here we have it in black and white in the OECD report.

Point No. 2, on page 22, says that educational standards in Australia have been falling. Point No. 3, on pages 25 and 26 of the OECD report, is a mention of the OECD's concern about the state of Australia's indebtedness to the rest of the world and our current account deficit. The OECD notes that our monthly deficit, which represents about 3 1/2 per cent of GDP, is the third highest amongst OECD countries—a critical point, particularly as I know the Treasurer today will be crowing about the latest billion dollars balance of payments figures.

Point No. 4, on page 34, notes that inflation has always fallen in past recessions. Point No. 5, on page 43, notes that unemployment is likely to stay over 10 per cent for the next two years. Point No. 6, on page 44—and I will refer to this in greater detail in a moment—notes that OECD's expectations about how the Australian economy is going to perform in the next 12 months are very different from the Government's own bloated and overly optimistic projections about growth.

Point No. 7, on page 51 through to page 55, is an absolutely damning indictment of the conduct of monetary policy. The OECD makes three points. The first is that monetary policy has been complicated by the fact that we have too many objectives—in other words, on monetary policy there are two stools and this Government always falls between them. Secondly, it notes that in respect of monetary policy the Government always gets its readings on economic outlooks wrong, and that of course is a real problem. Thirdly, the OECD makes the point that the monetary authorities' intentions have often been confused.

Point No. 8, on page 57 of our scorecard, is that living standards have fallen. Again, this is not news to the average Australian; but it is a critical assessment from an independent, authoritative voice, the OECD, to ram home the point that in the last decade under Labor people's living standards have been falling. As we saw recently in the official release of figures, we now fall to the bottom third of the OECD league.

Point No. 9, on page 58, is that our productivity is very low in both the public sector and the private sector. Of course, the OECD has some very interesting information about the public sector such as that Qantas is only seventeenth when it comes to productivity, and that the unions have had too much say in the running of electricity and railways. Again, our country has fallen behind partly as a result of the failure of this Government to change economic policy.

Point No. 10, to be found on page 74, attacks the Government's trade policy. It says that it is a real paradox that we should be moving to lower tariffs and yet keeping, effectively, a high consumption tax of up to 50 per cent. It mentions particularly textiles and clothing. Point No. 11 refers to the fact that at the Special Premiers Conference we had sharp disagreements raising the possibility that that, of course, would jeopardise progress on a significant area of reform. What does that refer to? Between the lines, it refers to the fact that our Prime Minister used the Special Premiers Conference as a lever to get himself a few votes in the Caucus to get into the leadership. This is typical of the way in which these people operate. They will do anything, say anything and jeopardise anything to advance their own personal cause.

In point No. 12, to be found on page 79, the OECD says that corporatisation has some benefits, but that if we really want the full benefits we ought to privatise. We have been saying that for years and years, yet these people continue to refuse—because their union mates control the shots on this issue—to do the right thing by the very people they claim to represent, the employees who have been losing their jobs as a result of their policies.

In point No. 13, on page 80, the OECD notes that until recently we have had very little progress on waterfront reform. This is an interesting point because for years these people have been saying, `We've got the problem fixed. We are doing it now and look at the benefits'. The OECD completely explodes that. It also goes on at page 80 to explode the myth that basically shipping reform has been done and finished. In respect of shipping, it says that more remains to be done.

Point No. 15, which is also on page 80—and I will come back to this again in a moment—concerns tax reform. Of course Australia should reform its tax system. It gives clear and unequivocal support, as the OECD has now for years, for a reform of Australia's indirect and direct tax system. In particular, it notes that the existing tax system that we have now puts a lot of costs on our businesses. No wonder businesses are closing in Australia. When one picks up the newspaper one reads, `In future we are going to manufacture overseas and import back to Australia'. One of the reasons is that we have a tax system that penalises our very own producers in Australia. Instead of encouraging people to employ fellow Australians, we have a tax system, particularly Labor's tax on employment, which imposes a very significant disadvantage on Australian production.

Point No. 16, on page 81, notes, `after a decade of slow progress'—and how slow it has been. At the next election, Labor will have been in office for 13 of the last 20 years. If one is looking for excuses as to why we are in the mess that we are in, it is hard to go past the people who have actually had their hands on the levers, and that is members of the Labor Party.

At page 84, it notes at my point No. 17 that interest rates in Australia, for Australia, have been at post-war highs. But it makes an interesting observation when it states `even at unprecedented levels by international standards'. So there is none of this, `Blame the rest of the world. They have high interest rates as well'. That little myth was exploded again by the OECD. Point No. 18, on page 84, is a very interesting point to be found near the end of the report. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . wages policy did not deliver inflation performance comparable to Australia's trading partners.

That is a very strong point because the reverse of that has been a claim of Labor since 1983 when it came to office. One hears its members all the time saying, `We have a special deal with the unions. We can control things with the unions and that is why we have had a relatively good inflation performance'. That is wrong, wrong, wrong. The accord has, in fact, seen Australia having a comparatively high inflation record relative to our competitors as one of the reasons that we have fallen behind the rest of the world. It is one of the Government's favourite myths exploded in front of its very face. It is on page 86. I refer the Treasurer to it.

PARA.TAB: On page 87, the report makes the point—and it is my nineteenth—that faster progress in labour market reform is needed badly. The Government has been in office for 10 years; that is a damning indictment of its slow progress to date. Furthermore, I think it really puts the pressure on Labor to acknowledge the fact that it does not have any plans for the further reform which this country needs so desperately and which is a critical element of Fightback. Those two points—my eighteenth and nineteenth—will be picked up by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) when he speaks in support of this matter of public importance.

Lastly, my twentieth point is to be found on page 87, where the OECD says, `More vigorous micro-economic reform is urgently needed'. It ties that into living standards. There is a lot of economic jargon, but I say to the ladies and gentlemen in the gallery and to those who are listening that if we want to have higher living standards we have to run our country more efficiently and we have to do things better than we have been doing them.

There are many things that the Government could do to improve the incomes and, therefore, the living standards of most Australians. This independent report says that this Government has fallen down on the job; it has failed to introduce, with that sense of urgency, the sorts of micro-economic reforms that Australia needs so desperately.

In the remaining moments available to me, I will refer to and remark upon the comments of the OECD in respect of tax reform. This is an issue which the OECD was very strong about in the last survey it conducted on Australia. It said that we must reform our tax system. There is no surprise about that; Australia is one of the last countries in the OECD to make the sort of change that we in the Opposition are advocating.

This report exposes the scare campaign which the Prime Minister has been running for the shabby, self-serving exercise that it is. It is exquisite timing. PARA.TAB: I am absolutely indebted to the Department of Industrial Relations, which set out the background to how this Bill came about and was brought into this place. The Department of Industrial Relations, in the building and construction industry background discussion papers published in Canberra in 1991, sets out what the Government's construction industry reform strategy was. I want to go through that to illustrate to the people of Australia how government wastes their money, why people pay much more tax than they have to, and why it is incumbent on people who are in this Parliament to start looking out for the taxpayers of Australia rather than just putting through scheme after scheme that is going to waste their money—this one would cost about $10m over three years.

It all started with the announcement of Senator Peter Cook in September 1990 that the Government was going to subject the construction industry to micro-economic reform; that is an important point to bear in mind. All of this was done in the name of micro-economic reform. We just heard a speech about micro-economic reform. What this process illustrates is that, apart from being able to pronounce the word and maybe spell it, that is about all the Government and its members actually understand about micro-economic reform.

Let us do a case study of how the Government engages in micro-economic reform. Senator Peter Cook announced that there was going to be some micro-economic reform in the construction industry. Following the announcement, the Department of Industrial Relations produced a publication. The publication is called Reform Strategies for the Building and Construction Industry. It is a background discussion paper and it was distributed and discussed.

So the first thing the Government did was to produce a discussion paper. It then called a meeting of Ministers of the Labour Advisory Group; it got all the labour Ministers around the States to have a meeting to have a look at this. What did those Ministers do, now that more Ministers had been brought into the net? They established a working group of officials. They brought in officials from the Commonwealth, the Territories and the States. They decided, as a working group, that they were going to look at it. The Commonwealth then initiated a review into superannuation, redundancy and long service leave in the industry. What did the review do? It gave a `descriptive analysis of the operation'.

So we had an announcement, a publication, a meeting of all the Ministers, a review, and a description of what was going on. What happened after the Government got the description? The Government established a Commonwealth interdepartmental committee, an IDC. That meant that the Department of Industrial Relations, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Employment, Education and Training got together to prepare a discussion paper. After the meeting of all the Ministers there was an interdepartmental committee. We brought people in from every department and they produced a discussion paper.

What was to be done with the discussion paper? It was obvious—a national forum was called to look at it. Three Ministers convened a national forum in Canberra in December. No doubt everybody who wanted to come to Canberra to take part in it was invited; in fact, there were 200 representatives. What happened after the national forum to look at the discussion paper coming out of the interdepartmental committee formed as a result of the Ministers' forum and the announcement? The papers were published and circulated—the proceedings from building for the future—around Australia.

What was the outcome of the forum that was held in Canberra in December 1990? I am trying to keep a straight face—the major outcome of the forum was the establishment of four working parties. We had a Ministers' meeting, an interdepartmental committee, a publication, a forum and another publication. We now had a major outcome: four more working parties. The working parties were given specific terms of reference and they had to report back to their Ministers—the Ministers who started this whole process in the first place. There was one from the Department of Administrative Services, one from DITAC, one from DEET and one from the Department of Industrial Relations. The working parties reported to the Ministers.

What do honourable members think happened after the four working groups reported to the Ministers? Wait for it: a subgroup consisting of the four chairmen of the four working parties was set up to try to consolidate the reports into one strategy. There were four working groups. After that, a subgroup was set up by taking one chairman from each working party and consolidating them.

Let me just describe that process: the Minister made an announcement; the Department produced a publication; the Commonwealth and State Ministers got together and established a working group of officials; the Commonwealth initiated a review; the review described what was happening; the Commonwealth set up an interdepartmental committee; the interdepartmental committee produced a discussion paper; a forum was convened to look at the discussion paper; the forum published its documents; the forum called the four working parties together; the four working parties reported to the four Ministers; and the four Ministers put together another committee to consolidate the reports. After all that, the proposed Bill came before the House.

Do we know what the essence of that 10-stage use of taxpayers' money was? Do we know what came out of all of that? Does any honourable member think a blinding light as to how we are going to make the construction industry work in this country came out of that? Did a proposal come out of that as to how we might cut taxes or how we might get the Government to be leaner and work better and more efficiently? I will tell the House what came out of all of that: a recommendation that we set up two new Commonwealth agencies. We had that 10-stage process to recommend that we set up two new Commonwealth agencies. That is what this Bill is about.

This Bill proposes to set up the Construction Industry Development Council and the Construction Industry Development Agency. This means more jobs, more travelling allowances, more employment, more conferences, more publications—a process that could go on forever. I hope the taxpayers of Australia are proud that all of this is being done in the name of micro-economic reform. That is what this is all about. This is a proposal by the Government to introduce micro-economic reform.

What is the Council going to do? It is going to act as a national forum; it is going to advise the Commonwealth; and it is going to liaise with other governments. What a wonderful idea it is to set up a council which can act as a forum, talk to the Minister and liaise with all the other Ministers we have in Australia! That is a worthwhile project. We have so many government bodies in this country that we need to have a few more to liaise with them all. Then, of course, sooner or later we will have to have someone to liaise between the Council and the agency. There is no telling where this could end. It could go on forever.

What is the agency going to do? It is going to facilitate the development and reform of the construction industry; assist in the implementation of industry agreements; develop industry codes; and liaise with the States and the Territories and other persons. Never have one body when we can have two—the Council will liaise with the States and Territories and the agency will liaise with the States and Territories. We will have some more publications, some more forums, some more interdepartmental committees and some more working groups. Perhaps soon we will have to have a body to bring together the Council and the agency because that could well be done in the name of rationalisation and micro-economic reform.

We must not worry: this process is going to cost only $10.8m over three years. That is all it is going to cost. That is just small fry compared to the way in which the Government normally wastes the taxpayers' money. This is an example of the scandal that has become government in Canberra and the scandal that has become government in Australia. This is an example of a government out of control and an example of a squandering of taxpayers' resources. It indicates why we do not have enough money to pay genuine social security allowances, why business is overtaxed, why we do not create jobs, why we do not engage in development and why we do not get the Australian economy moving.

If only the taxpayers of Australia knew that this was only one example of what is going on in so many other areas. I just do not have time to go through them all. It is an absolute horror story of how things have gone wrong in Australia. The House should bear in mind that this is all being done for micro-economic reform. I will tell the House what the Government means by micro-economic reform: it means economic reform which is so small, so micro that one cannot see it. As I said before, members of the Government can say the word and they can spell it but they do not know what the substance of it is. When honourable members think of the Government talking about micro-economic reform, they should just think of reform that is so small that they cannot see it but which, nonetheless, will take $10.8m of taxpayers' money.

This Bill is going to promote the adoption of agreements in the building industry. The agency no doubt will go around the construction industry in Australia promoting this great model, the Victorian Building Industry Agreement. It has been practised in Victoria for quite some time and it is the kind of agreement that these councils and agencies want to introduce. The councils and agencies do not actually do anything themselves; they are going to promote discussions about implementation of other documents.

This agreement came about when employers in Victoria agreed to introduce a redundancy pay scheme above the award. An employer who pays into this redundancy pay scheme—at the moment from 1990 to September 1991 it is $40 per employee per week—gets the benefit of this agreement. The benefit of this agreement is that if an employer does something on a building site that the unions do not approve of, the workers do not walk off and demand full pay unless the employer is in fundamental breach of the agreement. The idea was that it would stop workers walking off at a moment's notice and demanding full pay; they would walk off and demand full pay only if there were a fundamental breach. `Fundamental breach' is outlined in clause 10.3.1, which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Where an employer is alleged to be in fundamental breach of the terms and conditions of this Agreement, the employees affected by that alleged breach may decline to work as directed in the area affected by the alleged breach.
The matter then goes to a disputes board. I continue:
Where the disputes board determines that the employer was in fundamental breach of the terms and conditions of the agreement, payment may be awarded for some or all lost time involved.
The disputes board pays the employees for not working if there is a breach of this agreement.

PARA.TAB: It could be thought that employers would have to do something absolutely serious to breach this agreement; the mind could conjure up all sorts of things. But no, employers can breach this agreement, for example, by having employees work in inclement weather; by contracting out more than they should; by not providing the right protective clothing; or by not educating people as to safety requirements. They can also breach the agreement by letting somebody without a union ticket onto a building site; that is a heinous breach.

This agreement has a whole code as to what one does to make sure that nobody ever walks onto a building site without a clear card. If somebody is found on a building site without a clear card, the boss is told. Clause 19.4.4 says:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that if the employee is unable to produce his/her Clear Card, he/she shall cease work and shall not recommence work until 24 hours has expired—
the employee goes to the sin bin for 24 hours—
and he/she has obtained a Clear Card and produced it to the employer.

If persons are found without a clear card they are sent off to the sin bin for 24 hours; they cannot get back onto the site until they do get a clear card. Then they are to take it up with the employer as to how somebody got onto the site without a clear card. Clause 19.7.5 says:
Where the employer. . . establishes to the satisfaction of the Union—
to the satisfaction of the union—
that he/she has been deceived by the employee as to his/her true Union status by the use of a false, forged or borrowed Clear Card—

the employer is not in breach. So, in order to avoid breaching, a person has to say, `I was deceived by a false, forged or borrowed card', but if somebody has come onto that site and has not deceived with a false, forged or borrowed card—maybe he did not have one or maybe he left it at home—then he is in fundamental breach. Not only does the employee go to the sin bin for 24 hours; everyone else can walk off the site for 24 hours on full pay.

PARA.TAB: Bear in mind that this is a productivity improvement in the building industry. One only gets the advantage of this productivity improvement by paying into the redundancy pay scheme. If one does not pay into that scheme, one does not get the benefit of this improvement—everybody just walks off. That is in the Victorian Building Industry Agreement 1989-92. I seek leave to table that in the House.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are setting up an agency to enforce, promote and implement agreements like that. That is what the Commonwealth is doing by this particular Bill.

PARA.TAB: I first came across this agreement when I was representing a business called Troubleshooters Available in the Federal Court and the High Court. This building industry agreement does not exclude labour contracts. It excludes pyramid subcontracting but it does not prevent labour hire. In fact, there is a clause in here now which says that that is going to be the subject of a separate agreement. So, in the Troubleshooters' case, even though the Government had these massive provisions which, bear in mind, are over and above the award—the award has to be read as the base terms, and these are over and above it—the Troubleshooters' arrangement was not banned by them. But there was a very interesting development in that case which indicated the real purposes of these sorts of agreements.

There was a meeting on 5 July 1988 between Tom McDonald from the BWIU—and this is all referred to in the Troubleshooters judgment—other building unions and Breen Creighton from the ACTU to decide what to do about Troubleshooters. The minutes of that meeting are reproduced in the judgment by His Honour Mr Justice Woodward. On 5 July 1988 one of the points they agreed was:

SPEECH.PARA: . the possible use of the Victorian Building Industry Agreement as a means of making life difficult for TA;

In other words, even when the agreement did not ban that company continuing its business, they sat down and discussed the possible use of this agreement to make life difficult. These agreements have all sorts of possible uses to make life difficult for people who really do try to run efficiency savings on building sites. They have all sorts of possible uses for militant union leaders who want to make life difficult on construction sites.

PARA.TAB: If we are going to set up an agency to implement agreements like this, with all sorts of possible uses on building sites, I for one am not going to be in it. I am not going to be in the expenditure of $10.8m over a three-year period on more bureaucratic waste of this nature. Everybody in Australia knows what has to be done on building sites. There has to be a reduction in union power and union militancy; there has to be the introduction of efficient ways of working, such as contracting; there has to be a measure of stability; a good deal of honesty has to come back into that industry; and that industry has to be given incentive to work efficiently and productively again. This Bill will do nothing of the kind. This Bill ought not be passed by this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill 1992, I note that the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs ( Mr Beddall) is at the table. I appreciate that he is present during the debate. This is the resumption of a debate that has been going on for some time now.

PARA.TAB: In outline, this Bill establishes two bodies to be known as the Construction Industry Development Council, which will be called the council; and the Construction Industry Development Agency, which will, naturally, be called the agency. The primary purpose of the council is to act as a national forum for the construction industry in Australia, enabling industry and government representatives to put forward ideas to promote and facilitate the development of the construction industry in Australia. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, of course, have the carriage of this legislation.

The primary purpose of the agency is to promote and facilitate reform of the construction industry. This will be achieved largely through the implementation of agreements between governments, employers and unions and through the development of codes of practice for the construction industry in Australia. The agency is to have a limited life and is to cease to exist on 1 July 1995. A board of the agency is to be established to provide policy and direction for the agency. A chief executive officer of the agency is to be appointed to conduct the affairs of the agency subject to the requirements of the board of management.

Clauses dealing with the membership of both the council and the agency ensure that these bodies are representative of the major interests in the construction industry. Other clauses in the Bill deal with the constitution, powers and meetings of both the council and the board of the agency and the financial arrangements and reporting requirements for the agency.

The financial implications are that the cost of the construction industry reform strategy, of which this Bill forms an integral part, will be approximately $10.8m. It is anticipated that this cost will be substantially offset by contributions from all of the industries involved.

To set out how this Bill first came into being, one has to look at the changes that have been progressively made over the last few years. Finally, on 3 December 1991, the construction industry reached a watershed in its turbulent history. On that date the key parties in the industry—the employers, unions and government—came together and formalised the growing consensus that had developed between them. The result is the construction industry in-principle reform and development agreement—a clear commitment by the parties to achieve substantial and genuine reforms in the industry within the next three years.

Other components of the Government's construction industry reform strategy—the establishment of the tripartite Construction Industry Development Council and the Construction Industry Development Agency—were also announced on that date. The foundations for a unified, healthy and competitive construction industry are now in place as a result of the actions of the Government.

As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) noted in his One Nation economic statement, since 1983 the Government has transformed the industrial relations landscape. There have been fundamental labour market reforms, combined with a dramatic reduction in industrial disputes and responsible wage outcomes. This transformation has been based on cooperation between employers, employees and the Government, with the accord between the Government and the union movement playing a central role.

The construction industry reform strategy is a fine, practical example of how the Government's considered approach to industrial relations can bring about fundamental and lasting reform, something that the previous Government could not manage to do. This reform, in turn, is part of the framework of a comprehensive strategy of developing a more efficient and competitive industry. This is bolstered even further by the participation and support of the various State and Territory governments.

The industry is in a prime position to take up the challenge presented in the One Nation statement by the Prime Minister; it is beginning with more than $1 billion worth of new construction work over the next two years. This is a challenge that we must meet. The construction industry reform strategy which was launched by the Government in December 1991 seeks to bring about a quantum leap in the production and competitiveness of Australia's construction industry.

This strategy is now even more important in view of the substantial infrastructure spending announced in the One Nation economic statement of the Prime Minister. The infrastructure program outlined in that statement includes expenditure of over $1 billion to upgrade Australian roads, rail, ports and airports. I certainly hope that Badgerys Creek becomes a major part of this development. Virtually all of the expenditure will be on major construction types of works. It will be a major item in welding these units together. The capacity to design and construct these projects to international best practice standards of time, cost and quality is essential if we are to gain the full benefits from this expenditure. This is what the construction industry reform strategy is designed to achieve, and I am sure that with the cooperation of all parties it will certainly achieve that.

The Commonwealth Government is committed to working with the industry to achieve the necessary reforms. There appear to be many questions related to this Bill and it must be pointed out that the Keating Labor Government intends to continue improvements in all aspects where the Federal Government has an input. To this end, it has asked the question: why reform? The building and construction industry is vitally important to the Australian economy. The industry employs almost 500,000 people in all and it spends in excess of $40 billion a year—it is one of the major industries in this country. It is an input cost to all economic activities. It offers large export and import replacement opportunities for industry and business and it is critical to attracting investment in new resources and manufacturing projects.

Problems beset the industry from all quarters, and the Government is continuing to eliminate where it can. Management performance, for one, is below that required of an international competitive industry. There is a long record of poor industrial relations and representation of employers and employees is fragmented over the many organisations—over 100 at the last count. There are many inadequacies in regulatory and approval systems. These problems result in a cost disadvantage of up to 20 per cent by Australian companies on international standards, which discourages foreign investment and certainly accounts for why we have the existing problems. High levels of contractual disputes continually occur. Low levels of research, development and training also exist in the industry. Low exports and poor quality of goods and services and industrial disputations and restrictive work practices have continued to be fostered within the industry and must be eliminated.

The good news, of course, is about the proposals. The construction industry reform strategy developed by this Government, industry and unions is aimed at lowering construction costs and creating an internationally competitive industry through substantial increases in efficiency and productivity. The strategy is about overcoming the problems which I have outlined above. An in-principle reform and development agreement signed by major industry parties, a code of practice to apply initially to major public works, and extensive consultative arrangements, including the establishment of a Construction Industry Development Council, a Construction Industry Development Agency and the use of on-site consultative committees, will ensure success.

Amongst all other items we will ensure that the workplace bargaining alternative presently provided by section 115 of the Act needs to be more clearly defined. It must offer a more effective process for employers and workers to reach agreement. Experience with section 115—certified agreements—demonstrates how constructive such arrangements can be. However, the Government, employers, unions and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, known as the AIRC, have all acknowledged the need for further flexibility.

The need for legislative changes was highlighted in the parliamentary statement of the Minister for Industrial Relations on 17 October 1991. The legislative changes will ensure that workplace bargaining will not occur in an `anything goes' way. The AIRC's role as umpire will be preserved to prevent exploitation. In future, section 115 agreements will be certified by the AIRC provided that the agreements meet the following criteria: they are genuine and fair to both employer and employee and minimum award standards will be protected at all times; they contain a dispute settling mechanism and consultative arrangements; and, if an agreement applies to a single enterprise, it must be negotiated through a single bargaining unit and be the result of consultation with the employees who will be covered by that particular agreement.

The amendments will not alter the penalty or sanction provisions under the Act. The Government's approach to workplace bargaining is based on cooperation and consultation with the parties to achieve meaningful change and ensure fairness. All members of both Houses will fully agree that the construction industry reform is now even more important in view of the substantial infrastructure spending announced by the Prime Minister in February in the One Nation statement.

The infrastructure program includes expenditure of over $1 billion to upgrade Australian roads, rail, ports and airport infrastructure. Virtually all of this expenditure will be on construction. The One Nation statement also provides for improved depreciation and investment arrangements for business which should generate further private sector expenditure on plant and equipment.

In a joint statement the Ministers said that the One Nation program is good news for the Australian construction industry where activity has been declining markedly and was forecast to decline even further. The construction industry reform strategy was launched by the Government in December 1991 and seeks to bring about a quantum leap in productivity and competitiveness of Australia's construction industry. The strategy is to be implemented by the Construction Industry Development Agency, which is a statutory authority. The legislation to establish the agency is currently before the Parliament. Under the strategy, a key focus will be developing major projects as model projects. Best practice will be applied from the planning stage forward covering management and the construction processes, including contractual issues, quality assurance, work and management practices, and the development of a skilled and flexible work force. Clearly, if Australia is to get the maximum value from the important projects they must be designed and constructed on time and at the least possible cost.

This is what the Government's reform strategy is about. Support has been received from almost all the States and Territories, all the key organisations and firms in the industry, and all major unions involved. We must press ahead quickly and implement the reform strategy so that Australia gets the benefit. We cannot delay the process any further, as is proposed by some quarters, notably the Opposition. It says that it will oppose the passage of the legislation currently before the Parliament.

The building and construction industry in Australia is one of the most significant industries in this country. It is an industry that we have sought to reform over the period of our government. In fact, we were the only government in Australia that, in the end, moved to deregister by legislative action the Builders Labourers Federation because of its role in creating industrial disharmony and resorting to illegal tactics in the industry. We did that; indeed, we did it twice because it had to be done.

In recognition of those changes, there is a need to go further and build on them to make it a more competitive industry. Yet we have had this extraordinary display from Opposition members in which they say they oppose the Bill but, nevertheless, trot out the reasons why reform in the industry is necessary.

This is not an industrial relations exercise; it is an industry exercise. The Bill is about reforming the industry. That means, therefore, that it looks at industry development and research and development. The industry spends less on R&D than does any other industry in Australia. It looks at training. It looks also at how we should sort out regulations which, in some sense, prevent the efficient operation of the industry and, because it is complete, it deals with industrial relations as well. It would be wrong to assume that one can solve problems in the industry by simply concentrating on industrial relations matters and that there are some simple, glib industrial relations explanations. There are not. Industrial relations problems reflect the problems of the whole industry, and a holistic approach is required to deal with them.

We are proposing to set up a reform agency which will look at improving productivity in the industry quite significantly, because that needs to be done. We seek to ensure that contracts are delivered on time and on cost. We will promote the building and construction section in Australia as a future export industry. We will engage in innovation by nominating, with the agreement of the parties, demonstration sites or special sites in which new methods of work can be trialled. New ways of doing things can be experimented with so we can learn how to do things better.

The Bill depends on there being a degree of cooperation in trying to achieve the purposes of reform. We have heard from the Opposition that one ought to make war on the unions. I would not want to contend that no reforms are needed on that front, as there surely does need to be reform. However, I do not think there needs to be the sort of—for want of a better word—reform that the Opposition preaches. Certainly, I do not think that one can reform the industry by trying to eliminate the trade union movement from it, as the Opposition seems to be arguing.

The key element of any reform process is that we succeed in doing something significantly better. The Bill will allow us to do that. We have had extensive consultations, ranging over most of last year, with the industry organisations and with the consumers in the industry. I refer to the Building Owners and Managers Association and the major investors in the industry. We went through that process exhaustively. We achieved an in-principle agreement which they have all signed and agreed with totally. They have all committed themselves to the goals of the in-principle agreement—stretch targets and hard goals—which were set down in black and white.

One of the Opposition's contentions in this debate is that there has been insufficient commitment to this concept from the industry. I do not know what Opposition members have been reading or how they interpret `insufficient commitment', but not only is the Commonwealth Government committed to it, but also the signatures of the governments of Victoria, South Australia, the ACT and Western Australia appear on the in-principle agreement. The signature of members of the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors—the organisation representing the major construction companies in this country —appears on the agreement, as do the signatures of members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Metal Trades Industry Association, a number of other trade unions involved in the industry, the Building Owners and Managers Association, the Building Industry Specialist Contractors Organisation of Australia, the Australian Earthmovers and Road Contractors Federation of Australia and the Master Plumbers and Mechanical Services Association of Victoria. We have a commitment by organisations representing the stakeholders in this industry to arrive at the reform targets that we have set down. This is an example of total and good cooperative reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford Mr F.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —A century ago, representatives of various Australian colonies were engaged in the process which ultimately resulted in the birth of the Commonwealth. That was in 1901. The federation movement finally won the day because the people of the six colonies shared several fundamental concerns about their future. Amongst these concerns were the questions of defence and immigration. The movement for federation was given a great impetus as a result of the belief that a federation of States would, as a single entity, be more successful in ensuring its own defence and in determining an immigration policy which would be of benefit to the interests of the nation as a whole.

PARA.TAB: When Federation was finally achieved in 1901 and this Parliament was established, Australians were the richest people in the world. The decade of the 1890s had seen the development of a new and unique culture and a blossoming in almost every area of scientific, artistic and engineering achievement. Marvellous Melbourne was already acknowledged as one of the finest cities in the world. It seemed as though the young nation was destined for great things. Unfortunately, during the early years of Federation, Australians made some very serious mistakes, especially as they attempted to deal with the economic and social legacy of the 1890s depression.

Apart from the entrenchment of protectionism and an increasingly over-regulated economy and labour market, a major error was the decision to build a new capital in Canberra. Since 1927, and more particularly in the last 20 years, Canberra has become the symbol of institutionalised distance between government and the people. In its self-satisfied, subsidised isolation, it has bred a caste of cocktail-swilling social engineers, whose hostility towards the business and legitimate pursuits of private enterprise becomes even more evident as each day passes.

Since Federation, Australia has been sliding down the international ladder. Ninety-two years ago, we were first. Now we can barely make the second eleven, and we are still on the decline. We are declining not only in relative terms, but also in absolute terms.

During the supposed boom years of 1985 to 1990—the period of the much publicised accord—Australians became poorer while our competitors became increasingly richer. Incredibly, the Government boasts that real wages have been falling since it took office and uses this extraordinary argument to defend its unholy alliance with the union movement. Australians are now confronted with the results of decades of regulation, protectionism and the huge costs of the monopoly rents extracted by pampered members of the industrial relations club.

The citizens of this nation are being gradually impoverished by this Government's self-interested pandering to the bureaucracy and the middle-class single interest groups. In these circumstances, it is quite apparent that, as previous Opposition speakers have said, the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill 1992 will achieve nothing except negative results. The Construction Industry Development Council and the Construction Industry Development Agency are simply two more expensive quangos. Both these organisations are supposed to oversee what the Government has the nerve to call its reform strategy for the building industry. They are supposed to contribute to its wonderful record of micro-economic reform.

Other speakers have indicated what these reforms will do, particularly for the housing and construction industry. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) gave an excellent outline as to how this Bill was generated. In reality, they will be clones of the other players in the Government's new game called `Reform by quango'. The new game could be subtitled `Jobs for second-rate academics and other people who have never had a real job, let alone been in a factory'.

It all sounds a bit like Karl Marx who, as Paul Johnson has demonstrated in his brilliant book Intellectuals, had never been in a mine or a factory, falsified his figures or used information that was already out of date, and was a revolting anti-semitic snob who absolutely detested the working class which followed him.

The Waterfront Industry Reform Authority has already cost millions, but many of the fundamental problems remain. I ask the Minister at the table, the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall): is it true that under the current reform process on the waterfront it is not compulsory to resign? Is it true that those men who did not take the redundancy payment went on the transitional labour list? Is it true that there are some 200 names on this transitional labour list? Is it true that these people have been drawing $600 per week and have worked only 15 days in the last six months? That is quite some improvement!

The security of tenure and job for life mentality has to be abolished. With the conclusion of enterprise agreements in the major ports, there is no longer any need for government intervention. The ports should be privatised and allowed to get on with the job. Like the waterfront, the building industry is legendary as a place of corruption, thuggery and union rorts. A few examples illustrate the extent of the industrial problems: compulsory donations to Christmas funds, dummy payrolls, and the wet paper rule—if a cigarette paper pushed out from the crib room catches a drop of rain, everybody stops work.

What this Government proposed for the building industry will have as much chance of success as the heavy fabrication enterprises that once provided the basic engineering expertise for this country—the basic engineering for much of what was the construction industry. The heavy fabrication enterprises have all but disappeared—at least in my home State of Victoria. Where is the Johns and Waygood fabrication plant? Where is the Malcolm Moore fabrication plant? Where is the Vickers Ruwolt fabrication plant? Where is the Welded Pipeline fabrication plant? Gone—all by reform. They are just holes in the ground or warehouses for imported goods. More importantly, where are the jobs? They are part of the one million, I would suggest. Where is all this expertise, built up, in many cases, over 50 years or more?

Today we do not even have the will to build a mine at Coronation Hill, let alone a major project. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and I agree on just one aspect of Coronation Hill: it is a relatively small venture. Today, however, the principle and will to proceed with even a modest venture is lost in the bureaucracy. We know the problem, so why have another bureaucracy when existing construction programs are already being thwarted?

Last year our major companies spent hundreds of millions of dollars in the construction industry. However, except for the North West Shelf, about half of the investment went overseas. Most of our consulting engineering companies have never been so quiet. It is not that their customers are not spending money—they are, but it is mostly overseas. What will the Council and Agency do? Cause more of the money to be spent overseas! There will be some very good jobs for bureaucrats and lots of money wasted on consultants, but actual change and reform will never happen.

What the Government really means when it talks about micro-economic reform is the establishment of yet another bureaucracy, costing the taxpayers tens of millions of dollars over three years, which achieves precisely nothing in the way of genuine improvements to the industry in question. Can Government members not see that the more bureaucratic interference, the more bureaucratic regulation and the more bureaucratic form filling there is, the less efficient an industry becomes?

I operate a small engineering business associated with the agricultural and construction industry. The agricultural engineering industry hardly exists today. It has been decimated since 1986 by government policy and policy changes, all worked out and recommended by bureaucrats. Australia has been at the forefront of very many major advances in agricultural engineering and in the construction industry. Look at the kangaroo cranes, for instance. But where is the agricultural industry today and where is the construction industry today? They have almost disappeared. They are almost extinct.

We do not make a production tractor in Australia today, yet only a few years ago Chamberlain in Western Australia made the only large 100 horsepower tractor in the world. H.V. McKay's Sunshine harvester works is no more. Until some years ago, McKay's was the world leader. Today, we do not even build a harvester in Australia. For a nation with such a huge and successful agricultural sector, the fact that we have no supporting industry is nothing less than a national scandal.

Government incompetence and bureaucratic bungling have decimated heavy engineering and manufacturing. Most scandalous of all is the fact that those who have imposed these policies have remained immune from their destructive consequences. These bureaucrats have not lost their livelihood; these bureaucrats have not lost their families; these bureaucrats have not had to face employee termination and redundancy payments out of their own savings; these bureaucrats have not had to borrow money at exorbitant rates to pay long service leave and holiday pay. Yet it is these bureaucrats who have seen the total destruction of many businesses and many families. They can be likened to the Nazi SS as they exterminate our industries and businesses. If bureaucrats were made responsible for their actions in the same way as company directors, what a change there would be. Better still, if they were made responsible and the provision was made retrospective to 10 years ago, what a case the 100,000 business people would have and what a case the one million unemployed would have.

As I have demonstrated, what we do not want is another bureaucracy. Just imagine another bureaucracy imposed on top of a union controlled construction industry. That would put the pyromaniac in charge of the fire brigade. It is a recipe for disaster. Australia could say goodbye to that industry, just as we have said goodbye to our agricultural engineering industry and our heavy engineering industry.

An examination of the process by which this Bill has found its way into the House makes depressing reading. It is, unfortunately, just one in a long series of costly and destructive pieces of legislation introduced by this Government. Since September 1990 this exercise has already cost millions of dollars and has achieved absolutely nothing in the way of either reform or development in the construction industry. For the pampered bureaucrats in their air-conditioned offices, nothing is actually meant to be achieved.

The world of committees, working parties, in-principle agreements, interstate fact finding trips, draft codes, seminars, prime ministerial launches and so forth is quite enough to generate the appearance of a very busy life indeed. Unfortunately for Australia, it will not generate one cent in export earnings, nor remove one cent from the overseas debt. Already this preposterous exercise has cost several million dollars and will cost a further $10.8m over the next three years. The only result so far, apart from a lot of hot air, is another totally unnecessary bureaucracy—a bureaucracy which will, of course, obstruct and impede the construction industry in this country. Australia needs these industries. We need the employment they provide; we need the opportunities they provide for our youth. We do not need more business extermination departments.

Reports emanating from Victoria suggest that V/Line is about to get into the road freight business in a big way. What a great idea! V/Line already costs taxpayers over $2m a day, so why not waste a few more million and get in the way of legitimate free enterprise business as well? This is what the Construction Industry Development Council and the Construction Industry Reform Agency will amount to: more intervention, less business and fewer jobs—except, of course, for a few highly paid bureaucrats and Labor mates. The quangos, paid for by enterprise and the employees in the construction industry, are to be used to control and hinder their legitimate business activities. It is another shameful waste of taxpayers' money.

One of the largest site works contracts awarded recently was in Victoria, and it typifies what will happen with the Council and Agency. The Victorian Government—or, more correctly, the taxpayers of Victoria—should not be in the construction industry; in this case, the earthworks in the Latrobe Valley. Such a contract should have gone to a private contractor; but, owing to union standover tactics and bureaucratic weakness, the contract was split. This occurred not for any practical purposes but purely for political expediency.

There are only three groups of people who should be involved in the construction industry: the client or customer, who needs a building; the builder, who organises all the aspects of the construction; and all those people actually involved in the building of the structure—the hands-on people. The more government departments that are added to this, the less efficient will be the construction process and the less likely the client will be to put up the money in the first place.

I do not think it is any coincidence that the decline in Australia's productive sector over the past 20 years has been as a result of increasing bureaucratic interference over that period. Although we as a nation have the ability, we do not have the will to build anything these days. The Snowy Mountains scheme, for instance, would not be built today. The Roxby Downs copper and uranium mine would not be developed. No other major project would be built. How long has it taken to consider, let alone build, the third runway at Mascot?

It is not the construction of these projects that is the problem, since we have already proved that we can do it. Likewise, over the last 20 years we have proved incapable of getting major projects to the construction stage. What would another department do? It would slow up whatever is being done, if that is at all possible.

If the members of the Construction Industry Development Council and the Construction Industry Reform Agency were responsible for the industry in the same way that company directors are responsible for their actions, there might be some small justification for their existence. But the bureaucrats involved will be responsible for nothing except some totally unnecessary taxpayer funded jaunts around the countryside, not to mention the palatial office accommodation, expense accounts and other perks—so necessary to ensure the continuation of the construction industry in Australia.

The proliferation of such expensive and unaccountable quangos has in the past 20 years become a major impediment to economic progress in this country. In fact, the situation has been summed up most succinctly by Hugh Morgan, who stated recently:

SPEECH.PARA: We have a Canberra bureaucracy out of touch and out of control, a bureaucracy that now constitutes a national political and economic problem.

This Bill is a microcosm of that and other serious problems facing Australia today. It typifies all that is going wrong with the nation. If it would only go away, how this country would certainly prosper.

PARA.TAB: Eastern Europe has found, after so many decades, that planned central economies do not work. Yet what does this Bill do? It introduces planned, centralised, monopolistic control of the construction industry. What stupidity. Surely we are capable of learning from history, of learning before it is too late. However, to see the real agenda behind the Government's trendy new class jargon, one need look no further than the composition of the so-called Reform Agency Board. The notorious IR club is about to form yet another cosy little quango, funded from the workers' taxes but which will no doubt preside over the demise of the construction industry and its employees.

Big business, big unions and big government no doubt regard this legislation as just another great opportunity to feather their own nests. Who cares if it is at the expense of the construction industry? Of the 11 members of the Board, not one is representative of small business or of small builders. It is hardly surprising, though, in view of the fact that all members are appointed by the Minister and have no doubt already been thoroughly vetted for their ideological soundness.

The composition of the Council is just as bad. It does not have on it one person specifically from the construction industry. They are covered by prescribed industry bodies. Needless to say, unions and governments are again grossly over-represented and their views will no doubt dominate.

Since Federation, this nation has been able to tackle large and small construction projects. We know we can do it. Our engineers are amongst the best in the world. Our citizens have the imagination and the energy to achieve great things. If only government and the bureaucracy would get out of the way. This Bill will see the end of the construction industry in this country and should not be passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill. I need to respond initially to some of the remarks of the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford), who is a nice man but I am afraid his understanding of this legislation is on the wrong track. One illustration always chosen of the recent construction history of Australia is the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the role that it played in setting in place a very large construction activity, shared between the private sector and government and involving unions. Very few people now would look back upon that and say that that was not a productive experience.

PARA.TAB: In my own State of Western Australia, the significant issue in regard to the North West Shelf gas project was the development of pre-start industrial agreements. Amongst many things, this Bill is about pre-start industrial agreements. In fact, much of the work on that project was completed ahead of time; it was achieved with very high standards of safety and performance—

TALK.START.PARA: —But without this Bill.

—No, the honourable member for Dunkley has it wrong. This Bill sets in place pre-start industrial agreements for the construction industry. The sad part about the honourable member for Dunkley's speech is that the industry asked for these agreements. This is not something that was dreamt up in Canberra. A consultative process took place involving the industry, and the industry said that this is what it needs. I have talked to many people in the industry and they say that if only they could get pre-start industrial agreements in place, many of our industrial relations problems would be resolved.

PARA.TAB: Woodside, operating on the North West Shelf, is now a very large contributor to our export earnings. If the honourable member for Dunkley talked to the seniors in Woodside, they would tell him that the conduct of industrial relations there is difficult. It is a difficult, dangerous site in a remote locality, and it has been successful because of pre-start industrial agreements. We cannot walk away from that. The fact is we do have those in place. We cannot wish away the workers. The sad thing about the remarks of the honourable member for Dunkley was that he was saying that either they are all terrible communists and troublemakers bent upon an eastern Europe solution or they do not exist. The fact is they do exist and they have rights.

Workers are often organised in a way that, from time to time, is totally unproductive. Many of the stoppages and frustrations on building sites are due to the lack of cooperation between trade unions and employers. That is being brought out in the New South Wales royal commission, surely. We all know that. But we will not get anywhere if we just stand here and say, `Let's not worry about that as an approach; let's just go ahead and let the private sector solve it'. The private sector comes back to us and says, `But we want you to fix it up'. That is always very high on the list of complaints. We have to acknowledge that. That is the truth of the matter. It is no good my coming in here and saying otherwise. When I talk to my local business people that is exactly what they tell me. One of the things they always try to get in place is an industrial agreement that will cover the site. Optus Communications, which is now setting up, is setting in place pre-start industrial agreements.

This legislation is about that. I want to try to persuade the honourable member for Dunkley that there is an element of this legislation that is very fundamental: we cannot get out there and compete unless we can be sure that we have a workplace that is going to be safe and in which industrial agreements are going to stick. Pre-start agreements certainly give us that.

I return to the experience with Woodside. It was a very happy experience there in what was a very crucial project. We could look at a number of other sites, but I would take up too much of the time available to debate this legislation. The question of pre-start industrial agreements is very fundamental. When we look at the practices they proscribe, we see that they are not practices that anyone in this place would find they could agree with. All sorts of restricted practices are listed there, and they have said basically they do not want these restricted practices on the agenda. It is interesting because some of them are traceable to unions and some of them are traceable to management.

What I find unfortunate about the honourable member for Dunkley's position is that the solution is not just to be found in management and it is not just to be found in small business. The world is not like that. Of course part of the solution is to be found with management and small business; no-one would disagree with that. But management and small business will not necessarily take on many of the major projects. They may come in as subcontractors, they may come in as consultants, but many of the major contracts that are taken on in my own State of Western Australia, such as the major rail project in the northern suburbs of Perth, are being taken on by large business. Our local government authority in the city of Stirling, and prospective employers and so on, would like pre-start industrial agreements because they enable them to undertake these projects.

I say with all good will to the honourable member for Dunkley that this is not about merely addressing a bureaucratic structure. It is not that at all. The industry is saying to us that this is what it wants us to do, and we are responding. I heard the speech of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) and his introductory remarks on behalf of the Opposition. I was dismayed because all he proceeded to do, frankly, was to list the names of who was involved and then bag them as if somehow they were involved in some sort of eastern European conspiracy.

People of the stature of those who are involved in this arrangement will not line up saying, `I will waste my time on a fruitless bureaucratic exercise'. I have been to eastern Europe and I have seen the death that that sort of approach brought. The sort of people who will be involved, like Paul White of Concrete Constructions, will not want to be involved in some sort of deathly bureaucratic exercise. He has a lot at stake, as do we as a community.

We really have to come back to the assumptions of the way the world is. I find it unfortunate that those opposite see unions in those terms. I find it unfortunate that they see workers in those terms. I have to ask: if we put together the ingredients of that approach to industrial relations and the removal of minimum award conditions, and combine them with a social attitude that removes the Medicare system, removes pension payments and removes low income housing, what do we have? Under the Liberals we would have a Los Angeles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said we are going to do that?

—That is what is in the Opposition's policy. That is what we would have—a Los Angeles. I say that with all due seriousness. If that attitude to the world is taken—we have seen what is happening in Los Angeles on our television screens—if we remove minimum award conditions and if we go out and bargain, there will be no equity within the community. This legislation is about award conditions. If we remove minimum health standards and minimum social security standards, and if we do not have low income housing, the future is a Los Angeles. I say that with all seriousness. That really is at the end of the Opposition's assumptions. Under the Liberals, we would have a Los Angeles. That is why I am challenging the assumptions of the honourable member for Dunkley. Unless we challenge the assumptions, we will not learn anything. Fundamental to these assumptions is the question as to the way in which we organise the world. In looking at the building and construction industry, the way we are organising the world is asking how we can better go about structuring it. There is an extraordinary list of very busy people in the industry, as well as State governments, who have given their time to set down a consultative mechanism.

PARA.TAB: One of the issues that we have not properly addressed in the past—those opposite have to answer to this—is the role of State governments in terms of significant bureaucratic impediments. I must give due credit to the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Greiner, who has been one of the significant reformers in this area. I have been here nine years and I have heard all sorts of States rights issues trotted out by the Liberal and National parties. They say, `You cannot interfere with State governments, because that is interfering with the States'. The answer is that States very often interfere with the productive activities of business. The States have more red tape, more bureaucracy, than has the Commonwealth.
