I have to say that one of the significant things about this matter is that we have actually dragged some of the States in here and said, `Look, lift your game'. And they have lifted their game. There is now a much better recognition of what is going on. We are looking at the whole situation. We are looking at a partnership arrangement between the Commonwealth, the States, local authorities and the significant players in the industry. What significant players in the industry? I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The signature of the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, the organisation representing the major construction companies in this country appears in the agreement, as do the signatures of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Metal Trades Industry Association, a number of trade unions involved in the industry, the Building Owners and Managers Association, the Building Industry Specialist Contractors Organisation of Australia, the Australian Earthmovers and Road Contractors Federation of Australia and the Master Plumbers & Mechanical Services Association of Australia.

Those organisations are not involved in some bureaucratic stranglehold. They are trying to achieve a better outcome—and it is significant. A better outcome for the industry yields many more jobs and much higher levels of productivity in Australia.

PARA.TAB: We may as well be honest about this. One of the difficulties has been an absolutely appalling industrial relations record on many major sites. We have seen it develop over the years. I recall my days in Sydney when Norm Gallagher and Jack Mundy were playing games with industrial relations there, watching the New South Wales Institute of Technology building being constructed and the inability of managers to cope. At least we now have some people saying, `There has to be a better way of doing things'. That is what this legislation is: a better way of doing things. I am saying that to Opposition members. I am not trying to make a political point; I am trying to make a very fundamental management point about how to get an industry going better.

Is it important to us? Clearly, in terms of 500,000 people being employed, it is very important. In terms of its contribution of 60 per cent to the nation's fixed capital expenditure, it is very important. There is a lot at stake here. The other thing that is significant is that in technology Australia has often been at the leading edge. The concrete pump, for example, was developed in Australia, and it is a very important development. We have seen it used on many industrial sites.

We can go around the major Australian cities and give ticks or crosses to the sites that are going well or badly. Across the board we want to see industrial sites working well. It makes no sense to have people out on strike. One of my most moving experiences while working in Sydney in a high-rise office was seeing a fellow knocked down from what was then the old Australia Club building while he was using a sledge-hammer on a brick wall. I mentioned to some people that I wondered what the safety position was. I actually saw this man fall off that wall that was 12 storeys high. No attention, no concern, was paid to industrial safety. When the men stopped work, as they ought to have done, there was a headline in the Telegraph referring to the outrage of the workers and another strike. The fact is that a bloke was dead. He had a wife and a couple of children, and he was dead.

It does not benefit any of us to have that type of situation arising. The issue will look after itself if we have proper pre-start industrial relations agreements that recognise safety standards. That is very important at the moment also because we have a terrible problem with asbestos in many buildings in Australia. It is an in-built negative in terms of our GDP. If we had proper pre-start industrial agreements and we knew what we were doing in the construction industry, we could remove the asbestos from the buildings. It was done in Perth the other day when a building was imploded, collapsed with the use of explosives, and the vapours and so on were able to be contained in such a way that it was safe for the people on site. That is the way to go about it.

I am saying to the honourable member for Dunkley and to those opposite that we have an industry that is very big, that has an output of $40 billion annually; but we can have a much higher level of output. We want to be in a situation in which we can not only operate our industry in Australia as a role model for good industrial relations but also, as is happening, incidentally, increase our export performance. We need to see our major construction companies operating in our region. This is not an issue about the flag; this is simply saying that this is where we live and this is the place to work.

There is already significant evidence of that happening in our region, where Australians are regarded as being very much at the forefront of proper construction activity. That is to be commended. We really cannot say that we do that properly unless we improve our own performance at home. This legislation is certainly about improving our own performance at home.

Why is it that when we go around industry we find that people always draw a distinction between cottage construction and major construction? They do so because the industrial relations in the cottage industry is good and those in the major construction industry is bad. That is the fact of the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —One is unionised and the other isn't, that is why.

—The Opposition rises to the bait. I am trying to say to those opposite that they stand here every day and label the major construction industry saying that the workers are hopeless, that we do not need this approach and that we do not need that. I go back to the point: while those opposite operate from a set of assumptions that says that people in the construction industry are not worth talking to or that they are all ideologues, they will never get anywhere. The issues will not disappear.

PARA.TAB: There is another interesting thing. Let us look at the most effective managers in Australia. This is one of the things that concerned me when I was working in this area. When I went to a site and saw all the signs written in English, I would say to the management, `All your safety signs are in English', to which that person would say, `Oh, yes'. When I asked whether the members of the work force had been tested to see whether they could speak English, I found that that never happened. It is little wonder that there was such a big safety problem. In fact, on some sites where the common language was Greek or Italian or Vietnamese, there was no built-in safety factor.

We, as a nation, suffer badly from that. Our safety record shows that the hours lost because of bad safety procedures are five times the hours lost from disputes. The construction industry figures prominently in that record. Again, we have to ask how we approach it. We approach it by standing up in this Parliament and supporting legislation that, like this legislation, is not about bureaucratic interference. Let us go through the names of the people involved. The Board members include Mr Martin Albrecht of Thiess Constructions and Mr David Chandler of Fletcher Constructions, who will be in this not just because they want to sit around and engage in a bureaucratic activity, and Mr Jack Ritch of AMP, Mr Malcolm Kinnaird of Kinhill Group, Mr Robert Milne of Hooker Cockram, Mr Malcolm Farrow from DITAC and Mr Bob Marshman from DIR, who are people whose obligation will be to try to get improved performance in the construction industry.

That is why this legislation is very important. Not only does it talk about an approach to industrial relations, but it also talks about how we will better manage our future performance in construction. We have a lot at stake here. It has always been the case that we look at the cranes in capital cities as an index of how things are going. Sadly a lot of the projects are stopped.

TALK.START.PARA: —That proves my argument.

—I am not unconscious of the fact that there has been overinvestment and overspeculation in top-end city dwellings in the 1980s. Some of the excesses of the 1980s were just appalling. People had not arrived as corporate entrepreneurs unless they had a building with their name on it. In fact, in Perth we are busy taking down a few names, might I add, as is the case in Melbourne, Brisbane and Sydney. We are just getting out the screwdrivers, taking down the names, and putting up decent names.

PARA.TAB: So we have got that fixed. The market has looked after that and, hopefully, the corporate regulators will fix that up. Maybe a few people will be brought to book over it as to why they wasted so much shareholders' money and in fact, to be honest, why they totally distorted our national performance. A lot of that money should have gone into other productive investment—the sort of industry that we referred to. A lot of small businesses missed out because, frankly, they were not sexy enough in the corporate eighties to qualify for the capital.

That is what we have to address in this place—how we can ensure that we have an efficient construction industry in which people will invest for the right reasons, and how we can have other industries in which people will invest for the right reasons. Sometimes we need mechanisms like this to improve the way it works. In other small industries, that is not the case. That is why I say to the honourable member for Dunkley that, when one looks at one's own experience in small business, one cannot always relate that to a bigger exercise. I have noted that in speeches here people very often tend to extrapolate from the small business to the large business. The philosopher Hume talked about the folly of generalising in those terms. One cannot do that; it just does not apply.

When one talks to the people in big business, one of the things they want is a proper industrial relations environment—not the sort that Hugh Morgan would bring, but one in which there are in place proper pre-start industrial agreements and codes of practice which outlaw restrictive practices so that will not come into contention.

In my own electorate of Stirling there is to be significant construction activity. I note that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Brereton), who is at the table, has been in Western Australia already looking at some major projects. We are talking about very significant changes. I have talked to the employers in these organisations, such as Dominion Mining with the Yakabindie nickel project. Part of that is construction because there will be construction of the mine site; then there will be the actual mining operation. We are talking about very significant yields there. I am very pleased that we now have someone whose basic responsibility is to ensure that we keep a watch on this—not to interfere but to get things out of the way, to clear the hurdles. That is the Parliamentary Secretary's job, and I am very encouraged by that. I am not saying this as a political point. I am simply saying that, if one is out there looking at Yakabindie or the Marandoo iron ore project and one has the Parliamentary Secretary representing the Prime Minister who can say, `What do we need to do to remove these impediments?', we have gained a great deal. Certainly management will tell one that, and certainly the workers on the site will, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do we need to get Coronation Hill going?

—I say to the honourable member for Forrest that this is the problem. It is like the situation of poor Yossarian in Catch 22 when he flies 99 missions, then goes to the commanding officer and says, `I have flown 99 missions' and the commanding officer says, `You have to fly 100 missions'. That is what the Opposition is like. We fly 99 missions and then we say, `We have done all this—
—This was a simple one. Coronation Hill is ready to go.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —Order! The honourable member for Forrest!

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite then say, `What about this?' We say, `But we have done that, too' and then they say, `But what about this?'. They have an endless wish list. We are in the real world. The real world does not consist of a few ideological positions that those opposite build into their policies. I have listened to their speeches. I heard the honourable member for Forrest and that is why I say to him that he takes this approach to industrial relations: `Let us remove minimum award conditions; let us remove health insurance; let us ensure that people do not have access to low income housing; let us ensure that we remove all sorts of social security'. What we would end up with would be Los Angeles. Under the Libs, Australia would be another Los Angeles where people would not have an equity and would not have a stake. Those opposite have to come back to their set of assumptions.
—No, the honourable member is wrong.
—Order! The honourable member for Dunkley will cease interjecting.

—Those opposite protest too much. What those opposite would end up with would be their set of assumptions. From the industrial relations point of view the set of assumptions is a very bleak world. Well, I have news for them. Out there are a lot of very good business people and workers represented by trade unions who want to get on with the job.

PARA.TAB: I conclude on this remark: this legislation is about getting on with the job. It is about setting in place a proper Construction Industry Development Council and a Construction Industry Development Agency and setting in place pre-start industrial agreements that will enable us to get on with the job in construction. That is why this legislation deserves support and I commend the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) and my colleagues for supporting this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thrust of this Bill is very much in line with what the Government is on about in education, in compulsory trade unionism and the dominance of the trade union movement in the construction industry. I draw the attention of the House to the attitude and the policies of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in centralising the control of education in Canberra. The thrust of this Bill is another attempt by a central agency to run the construction industry by regulation and by coercion in the hope that it might improve.

PARA.TAB: I commend to members of the House the speech by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) who has had a long experience in industrial relations matters both personally and from his own observations. His basic thrust, with which I entirely agree, is that this Bill is based on the power of the trade union movement, and in particular the power of the building unions.

The Bill bases a lot of its standards on the lower standards of those bigger, more powerful unions and the dominant builders in the commercial building sector. The Bill is an integral part of what the Government calls its construction industry reform strategy. For reasons that I will allude to later, the Government seems no longer to want to call this pathetic attempt at micro-economic reform a building and construction industry reform strategy.

I would like firstly to discuss part 3 of the Bill which establishes the Construction Industry Development Agency, with a sunset provision, I am pleased to say, of 1 July 1995. The real power resides in the agency's board, whose members are appointed under clause 20. It is notable that the Minister for Industrial Relations has almost complete discretion as to whom to appoint—a very important aspect of the Bill.

Any reform process must have the support of the industry. It is a scandalous situation that this new body, established with $10.8m in government funding, has no representative from the specialist contractors or smaller contractors; other speakers have alluded to this. Not only are they such an important force in the so-called cottage industry—a somewhat derisory term, I think, for an industry whose average cost of construction due to its lack of union coverage is some 45 per cent lower than it would be if the residential building sector were fully unionised; contractors overall form some 84 per cent of the work force in the entire building and construction industry. The subcontractors in the residential building industry and their sensible working practices keep the price of an average $115,000 new home at $15,000 below what it would cost if the tentacles of the unions—whether overtly or by stealth—were grasping the domestic construction sector. The only industry representatives come from companies of the scale of Hooker Cockram, Lend Lease and the Fletcher Challenge subsidiary, Fletcher Construction.

The Government's in-principle reform and development agreement states that its objective is to reform the construction industry nationally. That is what I mentioned in my opening remarks. This is the attitude of the Government to change the thing on a national basis, not an industry by industry basis or at the construction site level. In a rather hidden division 7, clause 54 gives the Minister the power to order the board to comply with written directions—quite a sinister suggestion.

To look at the intent of this Government, we have to go well beyond the Bill that we have before the House tonight. An interesting document entitled Improving Work Practices in the Australian Building Industry by Professor Ireland, published in 1988, made many recommendations. It should have been compulsory reading for Mr Peter Berry, an adviser to the Minister for Industrial Relations, who stated late last year that the biggest problems facing the industry were incompetent and criminal employers. That is a very powerful suggestion to put forward, and I do not agree with it. What an odd attitude for a government that has paraded its so-called accord for all to see. I suggest that Professor Ireland may well disagree with that observation.

Professor Ireland recommended secret ballots to approve strike action where more than 5 per cent of time had been lost due to industrial action. He suggested that no direct payments be made to employees on days on which there is inclement weather. He commented on the difference in time lost on commercial and industrial sites in the UK and the USA—typically about 2 per cent there compared with the 10 or 11 per cent in Australia. Professor Ireland also stated that in the United States on-costs for builders ranged from 8 per cent to just over 10 per cent. In Australia, businesses are struggling under a burden of paying close to an extra 45c in every dollar. It is no wonder that our unionised sections of the building and construction industries are uncompetitive.

Will the Bill address these issues? The Government's reform strategy gives us little hope. Honourable members should listen to these two opposing objectives, set out on the same page. Objective 7 states that an aim is to encourage more efficient and flexible work practices and arrangements. Let us remember that. Objective 13 is to ensure that there is strict adherence with accord and agreement provisions.

In the Opposition's view, they are in direct conflict. On the one hand, the Government's accord process and adherence to award provisions is in contradistinction to our approach to making more flexible working arrangements, especially in the building industry. These two statements could cover almost any case. If there is little flexibility, the Government could say that its strategy is working under the latter objective. This might be despite the rights of the thousands of subcontractors or the rights of builders being effectively trampled upon by a policy of callous omission.

The Keating Government sees little wrong with an approach to industrial relations that knows only compulsion. We see it in the proposed increases to compulsory employer funded superannuation from 1 July this year, the Government's proposal. We, on this side of the House, are hopeful that that proposal does not get up. It also shows itself in the training guarantee levy and, revealed more in what is not in the Bill than the actual clauses we are discussing, it is again shown today.

The building and construction industry in Victoria is suffering very badly from this deliberate recession that we `had to have'. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has said that over the last year the number employed is down 21.5 per cent to just over 118,000 persons. This represents a drop of three times the magnitude experienced by any other major industry sector in my own debt-ridden State of Victoria. Engineering construction in that State is down over 32 per cent on the previous year and does not make happy statistical bedtime reading, to say the least.

Whilst some of this can be attributed to the cyclical nature of the industry, most of the decline can be laid fairly and squarely at the feet of the present Keating Government, which has presided over the loss of 90,000 jobs within the last year in the State of Victoria and seen the latest projected new expenditure on capital by business drop a further 11 per cent. We do not need to look at the official figures in Victoria, or the policies of this Government, to understand how badly the Labor Government under Premier Kirner has performed in that State.

As with any industry in dire straits, radical measures need to be adopted. We look in vain in the Bill for any ending to iniquitous compulsory unionism. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) and the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) are very much on the public record as indicating the pressure for compulsory unionism in the building industry. The order of the day is `no ticket, no start'. Yet a discussion paper prepared by counsel assisting the Royal Commission into Productivity in the Building Industry in New South Wales clearly showed what could be achieved if time lost through inclement weather, safety and industrial stoppages was reduced from 30 per cent to 10 per cent and, concurrently, a system rewarding the employee more for the time he or she was on site was introduced.

That inquiry produced some very startling figures on the lack of productivity because of inclement weather and industrial disputes. The discussion paper suggested that hours should be paid only on the basis of those worked, which would rise from 36 hours to 46 hours out of the 51 hours available during a possible working week. That sounds very good in theory, but if this is the only focus, past mistakes will be repeated. We need to have a climate in which genuine enterprise agreements—at either the individual employer or individual project level—are encouraged, but without the threats of intimidation, of black bans, or of any refusal to countenance the use of non-union labour that even so-called respectable organisations such as the Builders Workers Industrial Union have been known to employ from time to time.

It is significant that the Government has left the building industry officially out of its reform strategy. Why? Because the builders of the Australian dream house show just what can be achieved by contractors working for themselves, rather than at the behest of some union shop steward. Of course, this is not popular with the present Government because its ACTU mates are dead against the private contractors and they see a threat to union membership in the building industry and throughout Australia.

As Mr Alan Hickinbotham, the large South Australian home builder, the Hickinbotham Group, said in the Australian Financial Review on 23 March, `Any Government "reforms" of the residential housing industry could increase prices by $2,000-$4,000'. Australia clearly needs to bring the clients of the building and construction industry into sharp focus. If this is not the case, there will continue to be a smaller industry both in Victoria and nationally than should be the case. Why cannot both builders and their employees, together with subcontractors, realise that both the nation and themselves lose out if sensible agreements are not entered into at the individual level, as has been the case with the subcontractors and their builders?

Reform should not be imposed by a small, unrepresentative board subject to blatant political interference such as this Bill sets out to do. It has to come from within. It is very much part of coalition policy that enterprise agreements and genuine approaches by those working in the industry should emerge from the builders and the work force on particular building sites.

The Construction Industry Development Council established under clause 4 is more widely based than the Construction Industry Development Agency, but there is only a statutory requirement under clause 11(1) to meet at least once a year. That is a remarkable situation. One wonders how much value one can get out of that particular group. There would be no `funny money' payments under the iniquitous CERT scheme that some of my colleagues have discussed in earlier speeches, and whilst the ordinary time rate would remain at $12.39, site allowances would rise from $102 to $368 at a typical commercial project in the centre of Sydney. Provided employers profits would be enhanced by having workers on site for more hours of the week, they would benefit. The pre-tax earnings of employees would rise by up to $266 per week, but the actual cost to the employer per hour would fall from $27.55 to $26.69. So we see that if we improve the productivity of employees on the job in the Australian construction industry, especially in the commercial construction industry, we will achieve remarkable gains in productivity.

Unlike the economic statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), these are achievable, rather than the very rubbery growth rate figures of 4 3/4 per cent which are supposed to take place on 1 July. I do not see any signs of that happening. What does the Government do? In part 3, clause 14, it reiterates a commitment to the so-called `top down' strategy which has failed on so many previous occasions.

The report of the working party from the Department of the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) completed in March 1991, suggested that the new Agency sought to be established under this Bill should develop as a priority measure to assist the creation of a single award for the industry. Now we come to some of the real punch lines. As I said, a single award for the whole industry, nationally based, would combine the building industry and the commercial building sector.

The scrutineering role of the Agency must be called into question. No doubt those present on the opposite side of the House would say that the market has failed in respect of the large numbers of subcontractors who have been thrown into liquidation from time to time. It must be remembered that these subcontractors accept the risk factor, especially under the Keating Government. Most of them want the freedom to work for as many hours as they choose and have little difficulty in being remunerated for the hours actually worked and the achievement of the task that they set out to do. On many of the bigger projects those involved in the labour put in the hours but do not achieve the work programs that are set out on a day by day basis.

The acid test is that the cost of domestic building is some 45 per cent lower than in the commercial and industrial arenas where there is a plethora of one out, all out, rain allowances, heat allowances, wet area allowances, overtime, one in, all in. Even Lewis Carroll would be in wonderment about the remarkable number of oncosts that keep being added to these commercial projects.

Will all these powers of scrutiny mean that closed shop unionism by stealth will appear in the so-called cottage industry? This is what the Opposition is so worried about. This Government really believes in the so-called right to strike. There is no more an absolute right to strike than there is the right to impose my wishes on my next door neighbour. It must depend on the circumstances and reasonable dialogue between the parties.

The creation of super unions in most areas has occurred at the same time as union membership has been falling to a coverage level of only 31 per cent in the private sector. I think all Australians should be very aware that union coverage in Australia is only 31 per cent in the private sector. There is an impression in the community amongst voters that the unions have a greater coverage than that. Of course, the thrust of this Government—this Bill is part of it—is to maintain union strength by union amalgamation and by bringing in Bills such as this that maintain the situation of no ticket, no start.

Let us remember that under Mr Hawke, when he was Prime Minister, trade union membership declined. It was a remarkable situation. It will continue to decline as this Government introduces Bills such as this which are brought in for the very purpose of ensuring that trade union membership is maintained against the thrust of the industry which has an inclination and a desire to employ subcontractors. To not extend closed shops to small private contractors and builders of a subcontracting nature would be a benefit to all industries.

There is little pressure for change from within. Most clients of the smaller builders and subcontractors are pretty happy with those they engage. Of course, there will always be some rotten eggs, but the introduction of compulsory unionism would impose far more cost on the average wage earner who buys his or her first home than those relatively few shysters in the industry.

I, along with other members of the coalition, cannot support the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill, however laudable some of its objectives are. I note some of the comments of those opposite in supporting some of their theoretical objectives. The Australian construction industry along with its omitted colleague, the house building industry, deserves better than to be treated in this cavalier, compulsion based approach that is the case with this Bill, which is notable not for what is contained therein but for what is omitted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to enter this debate and support the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill 1991. The Bill represents an endeavour on the part of the Government to implement a reform process in the building and construction industry that is one of a series of reforms this Government has been about in improving the economic viability of a number of our key industries. It is the latest in a series of those cooperative strategies that has been built in consultation with those directly involved in the industry—employer and employee representatives—and, of course, relevant government bodies.

PARA.TAB: There has been, quite properly, some mention during this debate about similar strategies that have been adopted in other industries. Before I go to the specifics of the building industry, I too would like to refer to a couple of those areas. The foremost amongst those are the reforms that have taken place on the waterfront and stevedoring industries where the Government has been instrumental in seeking major changes in work and management practices to improve the efficiency on our wharves.

Those opposite at each turn seek to decry those achievements or to ignore them, but I think it is important that the record be set straight. The reforms that have been undertaken on the waterfront have seen the most dramatic improvement in efficiencies in that area certainly in peacetime. In the bulk cargo area, grain handling now involves a labour component of between 50 per cent and 80 per cent less than was the case only 12 to 18 months ago. The turnaround time for grain handling vessels has dropped from 4 1/2 days to 2 1/2 days. Indeed, in November last year, the Australian Wheat Board in its annual report recorded that the improvements were so dramatic that it now regarded Australian grain handling ports as amongst the most efficient anywhere in the world, saving Australian grain producers some $10m a year. That fact has been recognised generally in the broad economic debate, even if it has not been recognised by the Opposition.

In the Australian Financial Review of 31 October last year, Peter Roberts penned an article under the headline `Full Marks on the Waterfront'. There he set out the improvements that have occurred in the stevedoring industry with the containerisation handling capacity of our ports. I draw the attention of honourable members to the improvements that have occurred there. The article referred to the turnaround of containers per hour in Australian ports and, in particular, looked at the improvements that have occurred in the port of Melbourne. It commented that not so long ago we had a turnaround of about 12 or 13 containers per hour. Directly as a result of reform processes initiated by this Government in association with the industry, that number of containers has increased from 12 or 13 per hour to 22 per hour; indeed, on an international comparative basis, we now rank amongst the best in the world in the turnaround of our containers.

The article referred to some of the European ports. It is worth noting that the port of Melbourne has a turnaround of 22 containers per hour; Felixstowe, 19.7; Hamburg, 27.4; Bremerhaven, 21; and Zeebrugge, 19.5. We rank amongst the best container port handling facilities in the world today, yet only a year or two ago that was not the case. In the shipping industry, again often cited as an area where work practices have not been internationally competitive, Australia this year will crew its ships at less than the OECD average. Five years ago, in most cases, it was about 20 or 30 per cent above the OECD average. This year it is below the OECD average.

If there had been a massive strike on the wharves, or if all Australian shipping had stopped in the last 12 months for a period of some weeks while these reforms were negotiated, and the Government rode in on a white charger and got that sort of result, the entire nation would know about it and would say what a tremendous achievement it had been. But this Government has not been about disruption or confrontation; it has been about genuine improvement in work practices. In those two critical areas—on the wharf and in the merchant navy—often cited by the Opposition and their supporters outside this place, the improvements have been dramatic. They now place us on a par with the best practices in the world; they have been done by cooperation.

Who has been at the forefront of that cooperation? It has been the very workers and unionists those opposite have been at pains to attack throughout this debate. Opposition members have got their minds fixed in the 1950s. It is about time they understood that a total change has gone through Australia in industrial relations in the last decade; a change which has swept them by; a change which I am amazed they still refuse to acknowledge.

Industrial relations in the 1990s is not the industrial relations of the 1970s. That is a fact well understood by the trade union movement, by the workers in the workplace and by business people in the community involved in these negotiations. Conaust, a major stevedoring company, is on the record as acknowledging an 80 per cent improvement in productivity in one year. The business community knows that is the case. It is about time the Opposition stopped trying to peddle the sorts of myths and stories of the 1950s that had some application as we went through the 1960s and even into the 1970s, but have long since gone from our industrial relations and social fabrics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Norm is still there.

—The BLF has been mentioned; good old Norm! I will say a few things about the BLF because in any debate on the building and construction industry it always comes up. Those opposite have been very pious in their attitude towards the BLF throughout the debate. But the facts are that the labour movement brought the BLF to book—the Labor Party and the trade union movement. The labour movement internally disciplined the Builders Labourers Federation. The Trades and Labour Council and the ACTU disciplined the BLF and, in fact, expelled it because its practices were intolerable. A State Labor government and a Federal Labor government took action to deregister it.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that the labour movement sought to clean out the problems which the BLF had introduced into the system. It is important when we say that not to generalise too much because those involved enough to know would appreciate that it was not the BLF throughout the country that was deregistered, nor did it deserve to be. The BLF in a number of States is a very reputable and respectable organisation—respected by the industry, by employers and by its peers.
Mr Prosser interjecting —

TALK.START.PARA: —The sort of comic mockery from those opposite indicates the shallowness of their understanding of the issue and of the operations of the BLF.
—The BLF is still alive and well.

—The honourable member should talk to his colleagues in Queensland, because the Builders Labourers Federation in Queensland is a well-respected organisation. I might say that employers supported the BLF when it was suggested that the BLF should be deregistered across the nation. PARA.TAB: In any event, let us turn to the construction industry. The building and construction industry is important to this country for a range of reasons. It does represent a major avenue of investment. Some 60 per cent of all new investment in Australia annually goes into that sector of the economy; that is, some $40 billion goes into construction and building. It makes an important contribution to the economy. Streamlining its efficiencies will have flow-on effects throughout the economy, not just because of the amount of money involved but because it represents an input cost into virtually all other aspects of the economy. It is quite appropriate that the Government, working with the industry, should seek to weed out those problems which are affecting not only those directly involved in the industry but the economy as a whole.

This Bill has not been supported by the Opposition. It is important to understand what the construction reform process is about. It has been endorsed by over 21 organisations. I am pleased to say that the Queensland Government has signed its agreement since the original publication of the document. The objectives are worth noting:

The principal objective of this agreement is to develop a reliable and internationally competitive industry through real and lasting improvements in efficiency and productivity, as well as providing more satisfying, stable and rewarding employment for workers in the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that that is a statement of objective which all members of the Parliament would wholeheartedly endorse and would work out ways of implementing. Regrettably, it is not so. Members of the Opposition have taken it upon themselves to oppose the Bill and the establishment of an authority dedicated to implementing that objective.

PARA.TAB: Specifically, the agreement identifies some workplace reforms that are required and to set up a mechanism for implementing reforms on a cooperative and sensible basis. The parties have agreed to negotiate through the restrictive practices that they believe need to be eliminated, and to do that in the first six months of the life of the Construction Industry Reform Agency. It is a commitment to the process and it is a commitment to giving it priority. That is in the national interest, and the people involved know it is in their interests as well.

Let us have a look at some of those restrictive practices. They are errors of judgment or behaviour on the part of both management and workers. They are set out in the document. I do not propose to go through them in full detail, but there are a couple of key areas that need to be mentioned to illustrate the point that they refer to problems of both worker practices and management practices. They include such situations as inclement weather resulting in workers' refusal to transfer between sites or the withdrawal of key personnel, such as crane drivers or first-aid officers; the arbitrary and unreasonable restrictions on movement of labour and materials; the non-observance of award provisions—and if there is an industry where that is a major problem, it is this industry; and also cash-in-hand payments.

Cash-in-hand payments have become a double problem because not only do they cultivate the cutthroat, go to the lowest common denominator approach to industrial relations, but also they are designed to circumvent the tax revenue legislation of this Parliament. I am pleased to say that some years ago the Government instituted procedures for prescribed payments tax in the industry which have gone some way towards overcoming that difficulty. There is a general broad raft of problems associated with the non-observance of awards. Other practices include situations in which employers have provoked industrial disputes by the dismissal of a shop steward or some other site personnel in an attempt to escape penalty provision of contracts, and the consistent refusal by employers to work in accordance with occupational health and safety standards and regulations.

Health and safety is a key feature in this industry but one in which corners are often cut. The people at the end of the day who pay the price for cutting those corners are not the accountants or the managers but the workers whose safety is put at risk. The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) pointed out some of those problems a little while ago.

There can be no doubt that the process set in train by this legislation is a much needed one. The commitment which has been given by governments around this country, by employers around this country and by trade unions around this country gives us good reason to believe it will meet with success. Why should it not do so? As I have mentioned earlier, the goodwill of unionists and employers, through the good offices of the Government, has seen these sorts of reforms put in place on the waterfront and in the shipping industry.

As I went through the material for this Bill and listened to some of the comments from those opposite, I wondered what it was that they were so concerned about, what it was that led them to oppose this legislation, to oppose a reform process and to oppose a consultative mechanism which has already demonstrated its worth in other critical areas of the economy. Is it because those opposite think that strikes have been a major problem, that we have this massive labour unrest and really need the sledge-hammer to crack the peanut? The facts do not bear that out, in spite of what the prejudice and rhetoric of honourable members opposite might lead them to think.

In the seven years of this Government, days lost through strike action per 1,000 employees stands at about 232 days, whereas in the six or seven years of the last Liberal Party government, it stood at 591, which is about 2 1/2 times the number in Labor's day. And it was not just the odd hiccup. If one looks at the figures on an annual basis, one finds that those opposite managed to break records year after year.

The industrial relations record of honourable members opposite is absolutely abysmal. I demonstrate that by referring to a couple of recent years: in 1990, working days lost per 1,000 employees was 210; in 1989, it was 190. When the Liberal Party was last in office, in 1982, 358 days were lost. That was one of the Liberal Government's best years; it was the second best year that it had. In the year before, 1981, 797 days were lost. That is nearly four times the number of industrial disputes we had last year. That is the sort of industrial relations record those opposite had. Members of the Opposition cannot say that we need to adopt their approach in this Bill because industrial relations is not working and because there are too many strikes.

Is it that labour costs have gone through the roof? If we look at unit labour costs, we see they are now lower than they were in 1981-82; so it cannot be labour costs. What is it that drives the people on the Opposition benches to oppose these measures? Regrettably, one comes to the conclusion that it is a dogmatic doctrinaire commitment to a philosophy that is not supported by the facts and not persuaded by recent programs of reform.

Recently, I got an insight into that from the Tasmanian State President of the Liberal Party, Mr Eric Abetz, in a radio interview that he did on the ABC on 23 April. Mr Abetz was asked about a meeting of the H.R. Nicholls Society that was conducted in Tasmania, and he commented that he had spoken to the organisation:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . which has amongst its luminaries such people as Peter Costello, David Kemp, Ian McLachlan, all who now serve on the front bench of the Opposition. . .

I can recall some years ago when the H.R. Nicholls Society, which conducted its secret meetings up on the Sunshine Coast, was concerned about the glare of publicity. And well it might be, because its policies are disgraceful. Regrettably, the Society now appears to hold pride of place in the Opposition. Mr Abetz went on and said:
John Howard basically embraces the H R Nicholls views and he of course is shadow minister for industrial relations.

There, I think, we have the problem with the industrial relations policy. Mr Deputy Speaker, time is running out and there is other important business the Parliament must deal with before the adjournment. I will omit from my contribution today some other comments which no doubt I will have the opportunity to present on another occasion.

PARA.TAB: There is, however, one important point that those members opposite need to consider in addition to those that I have already mentioned. There is a doctrinaire, nearly religious hold that some members opposite have with their idea of the reform of the industrial relations system, as if there is a particular structure which, having been legislated for, will solve the problems. For Opposition members, that appears to be their interpretation, their brand of workplace bargaining.
Let me just point this out. It comes from a publication put out by the Metal Trades Industry Association, an employer organisation. It was noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Japan has company bargaining and an amazingly good productivity record. America also has company bargaining, but a record on productivity growth that is worse than ours.
I am not sure what we glean from that system of bargaining and what it does for productivity growth. It continues:
Germany has an enviable productivity record, but a system of centralised collective bargaining.

Those opposite, in this and all debates which impinge on industrial relations, have failed to understand that industrial relations is not about systems, it is about people; it is about people interacting one with the other; and it is about people interacting on a fair and equitable basis in the knowledge that it is not always an even playing field, it is not always a just playing field, and that there is a need to have an umpire. There is a need to know that we have recourse to somewhere and that we also have the rights of representation. PARA.TAB: I commend the Government for its initiative in introducing this Bill. It is a good Bill. It will see improvements for those involved in the industry; it will help create a stronger industry for Australia; and it will be for the good of us all.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 2 April, on motion by Mr Free:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The objectives of the Bill before the House are: firstly, to modify the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act 1987—hereinafter referred to as the ANSTO Act—so as to provide the agency with immunity from the application of State and Territory laws; secondly, to ensure that ANSTO can meet national interest requirements in respect of the control and management of radioactive materials; thirdly, to establish the formal independence of the Nuclear Safety Bureau, the NSB, from the operations of ANSTO; fourthly, to allow the principal Act to take account of ANSTO's commercial activities in regard to the Government's 1989 announcement that revenues can be retained by research agencies and not transferred to the Consolidated Revenue; and, fifthly, to put in order a number of housekeeping matters such as the terms of appointment and resignation pertaining to the director of the NSB.

PARA.TAB: I will speak about some of the background to the legislation which is before the House this evening. ANSTO is the corporate successor to the Australian Atomic Energy Commission established under the Atomic Energy Act 1953. The functions of ANSTO include the undertaking of research and development in respect of nuclear science and nuclear technology, and the provision and sale of goods and services in connection with matters related to its activities.

It is the case that, in recent years, ANSTO, as with other public sector research agencies, has modified its activities in order to align its resources and activities with commercial imperatives of various types. The Bill before the House is partially in recognition of this fact—that is, the Bill enlarges the definition of ANSTO's statutory objectives to encompass the agency's wider commercial programs which it has taken on in recent years. By so doing, the Bill also accords ANSTO crown immunity for the conduct of these more diverse programs.

This aspect of the Bill has been in response to other legal matters which have come to the fore in recent months. That is to say that the necessary amendments result from a decision by the New South Wales Land and Environment Court in February in which the judge ruled that ANSTO was acting in breach of the New South Wales Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979. The ruling of the court effectively prevents ANSTO from bringing to its Lucas Heights research laboratories any radioactive materials for conditioning or damaged radioactive sources for repair. The ruling also constrains ANSTO's ability to create and store radioactive substances on site as a result of its various commercial activities.

The court deemed these activities to be outside the principal research function ascribed to ANSTO under its Act. Therefore, ANSTO was subject to New South Wales law. More broadly, the ruling revealed and reaffirmed the advice of the Attorney-General's Department that, as a statutory body, ANSTO, did not, under its principal Act, share the immunity of the Crown from State law, particularly because it was conducting commercial and other programs which were not implied or enumerated under its original legislative charter.

The action in this regard was brought by the Sutherland Shire Council. It sought to restrain ANSTO from transferring to Lucas Heights 17 cubic metres of radioactive waste held at the St Marys site of the Australian Defence Industries—the ADI—site at Penrith. The Council required ANSTO to remove from Lucas Heights some 2,000 cubic metres of radioactively contaminated soil which had been stored there following the decontamination of the former CSIRO site at Fishermans Bend in Victoria.

The court orders, which I have obtained, reveal the following four issues. The first issue concerns the safety of the storage of CSIRO's soil and proposed storage of the ADI waste was not at issue. The second issue was the judge's confirmation of ANSTO's expertise in managing the waste from either the St Marys or Fishermans Bend sites. The third issue was that the decision reached by the court accorded with advice from the Attorney-General's Department that the ANSTO Act did not provide that, in all cases, ANSTO's activities were those of a Commonwealth agent and, therefore, that the agency must in certain circumstances be fully subject to the laws of the State of New South Wales. I should add that ANSTO did not attempt to defend its immunity before the court. The fourth issue was that, as a result of the decision, ANSTO must not receive any waste or radioactive materials from other sites or activities. Therefore, the court orders signal that ANSTO cannot receive the low level waste currently stored at the St Marys site, and that ANSTO must transfer the existing Fishermans Bend waste to a national repository by 5 February 1995.

While the ANSTO Act has proved deficient in achieving this end, it was always the Commonwealth's intention that ANSTO operations give respect to all New South Wales State laws regarding environmental standards and so forth while allowing ANSTO to fulfil its charter. Consequently, the amendments to the Act serve to define ANSTO's powers in respect of conditioning, managing and storing radioactive materials. The amendments before us, therefore, will place beyond doubt ANSTO's national responsibilities in these regards. The amendments also extend to radioactive substances arising from other activities conducted on the site, such as those from ANSTO's commercial operations regarding radioactive traces and medical isotopes.

Other amendments to the Bill, which I will mention shortly, also explicitly detail the Commonwealth's intention to ensure that ANSTO's commercial programs do not compromise its crown immunity. I would point out to the House that the Sutherland Shire has a long history of opposition to the storage of nuclear waste at the Lucas Heights research laboratories. This concern reflects the extent to which the Shire perceives the issue to conflict with its own environmental and planning laws and its own anxieties about the impact of the presence of stored nuclear waste in a region characterised by increasing residential development.

Moreover, the Shire fears that, if the St Marys and Fishermans Bend wastes are both stored at the site, Lucas Heights will become a de facto national nuclear waste repository. Similarly, the Sutherland Shire Council has a concern that ANSTO's increasing commercial activities will give it cause to attract much more such waste for conditioning and management from other sources, as well as creating increased amounts of waste from other activities conducted in conjunction with the industry. As the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) appreciates, these are legitimate concerns. It should be in the Commonwealth's powers to provide the necessary information and inspire confidence in the local community that ANSTO's operations do not compromise its health or safety.

Indeed, the New South Wales Land and Environment Court orders relevant to the decision unambiguously affirm ANSTO's capability to store and manage safely low level wastes of types existing at the St Marys site and those which are currently stored at Fishermans Bend. The court decision states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also conceded that ANSTO has special expertise and skill in handling and storing of radioactive wastes and that although radioactive wastes are stored elsewhere in Australia . . . there is no other place in Australia where such wastes can be stored as efficiently and safely as on the land at Lucas Heights under the supervision of ANSTO.

In the negotiations concerning the transfer of the waste from both sites, ANSTO's own Safety Assessment Committee, as well as the New South Wales Radiation Advisory Council, endorsed the transfers and agreed that they involved minimal risks. The judge also found that ANSTO had kept the Sutherland Shire Council informed of all its planning and intentions in this regard. In effect, the legislation before the House ascribes a broad range of activities for which ANSTO is to receive immunity against State laws.

PARA.TAB: Clause 5(1) of the Bill inserts into part II of section 7 of the principal Act four new subsections which provide for exemptions from various State and Territory laws. The first two of these subsections specify the areas of ANSTO's activities which are exempt from the application of State and Territory laws. These broadly defined activities, as outlined in proposed section 7A, subsections (1) and (2), comprise the following matters: the organisation itself; the organisation's property and transactions; or anything done by or on behalf of the organisation.

The immunity also extends to ANSTO's commercial activities. The Bill, therefore, also embraces such areas as companies in which ANSTO has a controlling or other interest. The Bill extends immunity to any company, the company's property or transactions, or anything done by or on behalf of the relevant company which is associated in some formal way with ANSTO.

Subsection (3) of proposed section 7A specifies several general categories or classes of State and Territory laws to which ANSTO's operations, as specified in the two earlier subsections, do not apply. They are the use or proposed use of land or premises; the environmental consequences of the use of land or premises; radioactive materials or dangerous goods; or licensing in relation to employment, carrying on a particular kind of business undertaking or conducting a particular kind of operation. As a result of the new subsection 7A(4) proposed in the Bill before the House, the Commonwealth will be able to act through regulations to prescribe any laws within the classes of laws as defined in section 7A(3) to which ANSTO might be subject at some future time.

The coalition parties consider that ANSTO should be guaranteed the ability under statute to carry out its prescribed activities in the ways which best serve the national interest. Despite this, I must stress that in matters such as those in which ANSTO is active, every conceivable effort must be made to keep the community abreast of developments and confident that its health and safety interests will not be taken for granted or forsaken.

The grant of immunity before State laws, as provided in the Bill, also carries with it a very serious responsibility on the part of the Commonwealth, and ANSTO itself, to deal openly and honestly with the wider community. I know well that the organisation itself has made a systematic attempt in recent years to break down the barriers to the wider community and to become a part of that community itself. Its series of open days and the access it provides to New South Wales school students are examples of the kind of activity which often goes unnoticed by the Parliament. These efforts must continue.

The Commonwealth must be active, too. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce advises me that the Sutherland Shire has been reassured in these matters. I am uncertain as to the scope of these

SPEECH.PARA: negotiations. The issues, however, are too important for the Commonwealth not to put the legwork into building bridges, in creating a climate of confidence in these areas.

PARA.TAB: In considering the merits of the Bill, the following matters need to be kept in mind. First, on the advice of the relevant safety authorities and the Minister, storage of the relevant low-level nuclear wastes does not put public safety at risk. Secondly, there are advantages in the legislation in so far as it provides for public health and safety. The Government advises that if the court orders as mentioned earlier are accepted, ANSTO will not be able to bring radioactive substances to Lucas Heights for conditioning or for purposes of repairing damaged radioactive sources.

In the case of damage to radioactive sources, if a package containing radioactive isotopes for industrial or medical use were to be damaged in transit, it would not be able to be transferred to the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories' hot cell for repair. As a consequence of this, the damaged radioactive source could not be repaired, period, as similar facilities and services do not exist anywhere else in Australia.

Hitherto, ANSTO has strictly abided by all New South Wales environmental and pollution laws, and the Minister has made explicit public assurances that this will continue. ANSTO has an impressive track record in this regard and more should be made of its commitments to maintaining the highest level of environmental monitoring and assessment.

The legislation will also strengthen the independence of the Nuclear Safety Bureau, a move which will give cause for the community to have even greater confidence that the operation of the nuclear plant itself—the HIFAR and MOATA reactors—is in safe hands, free from even the vaguest form of interference from other interests. The amendments to the ANSTO Act establish the Nuclear Safety Bureau, which is now responsible to the Minister for monitoring and reviewing the safety of the nuclear plant operated by ANSTO.

The NSB is empowered to impose conditions or restrictions on the operation of the nuclear plant. However, ANSTO itself appoints the staff of the NSB and theoretically may assign the NSB other functions as it sees fit. This is a far cry from the existing arrangements, whereby the NSB acts virtually through the Board of ANSTO.

In the past, the coalition has called for a review of the structure of this arrangement for fear that the public might not perceive the NSB as acting in a disinterested manner in respect of the operation of the research reactors, especially in times of union disruption over alleged safety issues. There is no prima facie evidence of any sort that the NSB has compromised its role in this regard. The legislation, nevertheless, concedes the importance of the coalition's stated position and moves to establish the NSB as a distinct, separate and independent body from ANSTO. The financial impact—no doubt of interest to honourable members—will be $150,000 to meet the added administrative costs of operating an independent NSB.

The Minister has confirmed publicly that the Lucas Heights research laboratories will not become a de facto national radioactive waste repository. The Government has underpinned the amendments with public commitments to provide for the establishment of a national nuclear waste repository as soon as is practicable. This is the only fundamental solution to the problem at hand—that is, the safest and most effective means by which Australia can store and manage its various types of nuclear waste.

The coalition has endorsed the importance of giving consideration to the role of such a facility or facilities. Any reasonable progress which can be made in developing Commonwealth and State understandings in respect of the importance of overcoming the storage issue should be endorsed. Again, it is important in this matter that the Government act to build up a spirit of common cause and community confidence.

In his second reading speech, the Minister claimed the Department of Primary Industries and Energy was active in working on arrangements which would facilitate progress towards a national nuclear waste repository. This will be no easy task. As we have witnessed in respect of moves to create an intractable waste disposal and storage capability, there is a great deal of community anxiety embedded in these complex issues.

As part of the Government's claimed intention to assure the Sutherland Shire community that it has no intention of making the Lucas Heights laboratories the site for a storage of nuclear wastes, it has moved to order a full investigation of the technical, legal and other issues concerning the conditioning, management and interim storage of the ADI and Fishermans Bend wastes, and has called for a report by December 1992 identifying all practicable options. These processes are important for the community dialogue they create, as they are, too, for their ultimate findings.

The Bill also bears on certain administrative matters. The legislation also incorporates various housekeeping matters in regard to the employment conditions of the Executive Director of ANSTO, the lifting of the value of contracts which ANSTO may enter into without ministerial approval from $200,000 to $1m, the repeal of the legislative requirement that ANSTO transfer its external earnings to Consolidated Revenue in line with the Government's 1989 announcements, and the repeal of the intention under the Act to establish an advisory council to advise on and audit ANSTO's operations. This role is now carried out by several other internal and independent bodies, such as the program advisory committees of external experts. These are not considered controversial matters by the coalition parties. The Opposition therefore supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise in support of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill, which will amend the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act of 1987. Ever since Dr Oppenheimer discovered the explosive capacity which can be generated by the process of nuclear fusion almost 50 years ago, there have been many who have urged the ending of all research into nuclear power.

PARA.TAB: However, it should be recognised that there are many different ways in which our current nuclear science and technology can be used for peaceful purposes. In order to encourage the peaceful use of nuclear technology, the Federal Government legislated in 1987 to revise the role and change the name of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, ANSTO. This new legislation is necessary to ensure the Government's commercialisation objectives for ANSTO are fulfilled and to adapt the role of the organisation for changing circumstances.

The Government has been of the opinion that for research institutions to meet their full potential they have to open themselves up to the competitive environment of private enterprise through adopting a more corporate outlook. ANSTO can feel satisfied with the progress it has made in achieving this objective. It reached its target of financing 30 per cent of its budget through its commercial activities two years ahead of schedule, in the 1990-91 financial year.

The ability of ANSTO to achieve its corporatisation objectives has been constrained by the original ANSTO Act, making the amendments which are before the House tonight very necessary. These changes to the legislative framework will ensure that ANSTO has the ability to carry out fully the commercialisation of its activities.

Another change that will occur as a result of the legislation is in regard to the immunity of ANSTO from certain State and Territory laws. Determining the extent to which ANSTO, as a Commonwealth authority which is situated entirely within the borders of New South Wales, is subject to New South Wales law has been somewhat of a problem. Historically, the policy of Federal governments of all political persuasions has been that any bodies under its control operate under State laws where there is no existing Commonwealth law. Advice from the Department of the Attorney-General that ANSTO may be fully subject to New South Wales State law has made changes to the Act necessary.

The Commonwealth never intended ANSTO to be subject to State law, and it is important that this issue be addressed as it reduces the organisation's ability to function effectively and could even result in safety problems which are obviously unacceptable when nuclear technology is being used. To address this problem, ANSTO will be made immune from certain State and Territory laws. These amendments will be retrospective on the advice of the Department of the Attorney-General.

Another area of change is in relation to the Nuclear Safety Bureau. A national safety bureau was established under the 1987 legislation in order to monitor the safety of nuclear plants operated by the organisation. This bureau, which is responsible to the Minister, has its staff appointed by the ANSTO board. Even though the NSB is completely independent of ANSTO in practice, the manner in which the Act was structured left this independence open to question. The new restructured Nuclear Safety Bureau will be funded independently of ANSTO, ensuring that the integrity of its work is beyond question.

Several other administrative matters will be tidied up through the passing of this legislation. ANSTO will now have the ability to enter into contracts of up to $1m without having to receive approval from the Minister for Science and Technology, ensuring that its decisions are more commercially orientated. That is not saying that the Minister would not be commercially orientated anyway, but just the same I think it is worth making the comment for the present Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free). Some additional costs of around $150,000 will result from these changes in the short term, as increased costs will be associated with separating the two organisations in the manner I described earlier.

I turn to the section of the Bill relating to radioactive materials and waste. The Minister knows I have a bit of an interest in that area. How we as a community deal with problems associated with radioactive materials and waste is an issue of great concern to many of the constituents in my electorate of Oxley, particularly in the Esk area. The Esk area is currently in the electorate of Oxley, but with the Federal redistribution the new seat of Dickson is being formed and the Esk area will actually go into that seat, which my colleague the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) will become the member for after the next Federal election. The honourable member for Fisher has taken a very keen interest in that area, of course, and just recently he actually visited the area, along with the Minister for Science and Technology, who is in the chamber this evening. Both the Minister for Science and Technology and the honourable member for Fisher have certainly supported me in my concern about the people in the Esk area.

ANSTO—and its predecessor, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission—has been involved in the management of radioactive waste materials generated by itself and other organisations for many years. Its ability to carry out such a task was recently challenged in the New South Wales Land and Environment Court when the Sutherland Shire Council sought a restraining order to stop the transfer of radioactive waste from the St Mary's site of Australian Defence Industries to the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories. ANSTO had planned to store these waste products at Lucas Heights until a national repository for radioactive waste material could be built. A court decision in February this year found in the council's favour.

ANSTO was restrained from transferring any waste from the ADI site and was ordered to remove the existing waste within three years. This was in spite of the fact that Lucas Heights was found by the judge to be the safest site in Australia for the storage of radioactive waste products. This decision has the unfortunate consequence of preventing ANSTO from carrying out services which are necessary in the interests of public health and safety.

Radioactive waste is generated in several ways, including medical research and treatment, and it is important that an effective method of waste storage be maintained. The amendments to the 1987 Act in relation to this matter will ensure that ANSTO has the ability to store and manage radioactive materials and waste from its activities or companies in which the organisation has a controlling interest. These amendments are not intended to circumvent the decision of the New South Wales Land and Environment Court and ANSTO will abide by its ruling by removing the waste from the Lucas Heights site by February 1995.

The Environment Court decision has led to an increase in the level of community awareness of the need for a national repository for low level radioactive waste. I am particularly pleased that this item has at least been put on the main agenda. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has been seeking the cooperation of the State governments in investigating possible sites, and this has been going on for some time. A report is in the process of being prepared at present to investigate the issues surrounding the conditioning, interim storage and management of the ADI and CSIRO wastes. The Government does not intend allowing the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories to become a national waste repository.

As I said earlier, the debate over the need for such a national facility is of great interest to the people of the Esk Shire particularly, a community which is currently in my electorate but which, as I said before, will be moving into the new Federal electorate of Dickson. I recall that the Minister and the honourable member for Fisher visited there with me recently.

The Queensland Government's decision in February of this year to build a storage facility for used radioactive materials in a State forest outside of Esk, just north-west of Ipswich, has understandably led to a considerable degree of community concern. This move follows the State Government's repeal of a decision of the previous National Party Government in Queensland to establish a similar facility in Redbank, which is also within my electorate of Oxley. We seem to attract radioactive waste; I do not know why.

This project resulted in a massive campaign by local residents and the broader community including, of course, local politicians from all levels of government—including myself and the now Premier as well. The impact of this is that it certainly helped the Goss Government to be elected in December 1989. The State Government is, of course, to be applauded for listening to these community concerns. It faced the matter head on and really solved the problem for the people of Redbank. But it is rather difficult to understand how the State Government now can continue to ignore the concerns of the people of Esk.

No-one can deny that the State Government has a problem with the storage of radioactive waste and needs to establish a facility somewhere in Queensland, even if there is to be a transit collection point for a national facility. The problem has existed for many years and it was neglected by the previous National Party Government. It is another one of those big problems that the Labor Government in Queensland now has to tidy up. But radioactive substances are a fact of everyday life probably in most States, so there is an undoubted need for a store for the State's radioactive waste.

In Queensland radioactive waste is presently being stored in unsupervised stores all over the State. The State Government has correctly recognised that it must act in this issue to prevent what could become a major threat to public health and safety. The people of Esk are understandably very concerned that this facility is to be placed in their area, which is a centre of beef and vegetable production. When the Minister for Science and Technology recently visited the area with the honourable member for Fisher and me, I am sure that while speaking to the local residents he got the message loud and clear that they certainly do not want this facility in their backyard.

There is a danger that consumers will shy away from buying produce from the area if they know it is also the site for a radioactive storage facility, even though it is low radioactive waste. I have made my view quite clear on this issue to both the Queensland Premier and the Queensland health Minister at every available opportunity. I am pleased that my colleague the honourable member for Fisher has been supporting me in this and has also made his views known to the people in the Esk area.

Some would say that it is just an example of the NIMBY mentality, the `not in my backyard' mentality, which is prevalent throughout Australian society. However, anyone who makes such remarks is clearly unfamiliar with the area surrounding the Esk case. Esk is in the centre of south-east Queensland, an area which all social planners agree is the fastest growing area in Australia. This decision flies in the face of the State Government's commitment to the development of south-east Queensland as a residential and tourist area.

I find it difficult to understand how the building of a radioactive storage facility not far from the residential housing in the township of Esk can be justified by the Government in the light of its commitment to this process of development. Apart from the important social issues related to siting a radioactive storage facility in such an attractive and pleasant town, there are several issues relating to matters of public health and safety which need to be addressed.

One area of grave concern relates to the fact that the transport route to the Esk State forest, where the facility is to be sited, is in the water catchment area of the Wivenhoe Dam. Of course, the Wivenhoe Dam is the major source of water resources of south-east Queensland, including particularly the city of Brisbane. If an accident should happen at this radioactive waste facility, radioactive material could seep into the watertable, and there is a danger that this watercourse could be contaminated. The risks associated with the transport of waste to the site is also an issue which has not been properly addressed.

In the early stages there was talk that the route to the site for vehicles transporting the waste would be across the wall of the Wivenhoe Dam, the main Brisbane Valley Highway. However, the Government has since made it clear that these vehicles would be travelling by a different route. The waste will now be transported through Ipswich, up the Warrego Highway towards Gatton and then along the Gatton-Esk road until it reaches the township of Esk. When the transport vehicles get to Esk, they will go past a couple of schools.

Obviously this would have grave consequences for public health in the area and, one would think, would be grounds enough for a rethink by the State Government of its decision. While it is laudable that the Government is concerned to attempt to avoid travelling too near the Wivenhoe Dam, unfortunately it has overlooked the fact that the preferred route has three creek crossings, each of which is part of the Wivenhoe Dam catchment area.

If a risk event is of sufficient concern to discard the original route, surely the risks of contamination associated with the revised routes mean they are also unacceptable. Indeed, it could be said that the transport of the initial mass and, subsequently, of the fortnightly load of radioactive waste is the greatest potential source of hazard to human life and health associated with this proposal. As the submission on the proposed radioactive waste storage facility to the State health Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The hazard follows from the use of road transport and the consequent risk of accident especially involving the incineration of the packaging and contaminants being released as a lethal dose to any person or group it touches.
The potential for long term illness or `unconnected' later death when a larger number of people receive a sub-lethal dose, has not yet been disclosed.
