The driver of the transport vehicle receives a measurable dose in the normal duration of the trip, even if no container is crushed or burned.
It follows that distance is the factor which principally governs the level of transport risk.

Obviously the road transport over such long distances to the site of the facility in such an area is impractical and dangerous. The incidence of rail accidents is substantially smaller than that associated with roads. The nature, size and strength of rail rolling stock favours it in instances of level crossing accidents with road vehicles. The likelihood of a railcar incineration is very small compared with a road accident risk.

PARA.TAB: Rail transport offers the least risk for transfer of wastes to a national disposal facility when it is finally established. Presently there is not a satisfactory rail system which serves Esk, making it difficult for the site to fulfil any role as a transit point to a national facility when it is built.

One safety issue which has received little attention has been the recent escalation in the potential for terrorist style attacks on sensitive facilities. A radioactive waste storage facility, such as this one, which is remotely located and visited only fortnightly, would provide a real target for such an attack.

I would like to turn to the economic problems associated with the Esk site which I referred to earlier. Adverse publicity and association of a product or district with a health risk has the potential to destroy the marketability of the district's products. In accordance with regulations, fruit and vegetables produced in the region are clearly marked `Esk' and these products have always enjoyed a reputation of quality and purity. For instance, Esk is the State's top producer of watermelons. In fact, there is a watermelon festival at a nearby town of Coominya in about January every year. Vegetable growers in the district are now under a cloud.
Similarly, beef production is the major pastoral activity in the Esk shire. As the Esk shire's submission on the radioactive storage facility points out:

SPEECH.PARA: The beef produced creates export income for Queensland and Australia through the Korean, American and Japanese markets which are highly sensitive to quality and totally averse to contamination.
Currently there is a push by U.S. meat exporters for an increased share of the Japanese market.
Any hint of radioactive waste being associated with Esk beef . . . will be an opportunity for U.S. interests to damage the reputation of not only Esk beef but also the Australian beef industry.

The siting of a radioactive storage facility in the area has the potential to damage beef's reputation not only in its domestic marketing but also in its international marketing. This would cost Australia and the users of the Kilcoy meatworks, located not far from Esk, and the people of Esk considerable income. This decision is regrettable, especially in the light of the fact that another potential site, Beerburrum, has been discarded as a site because of potential damage to the reputation of the region's products. That, of course, was the right decision.

PARA.TAB: In all of this it has to be remembered that the decision as to where to establish a storage facility is one ultimately for the State Government and is beyond the jurisdiction of the Federal Government. That point needs to be emphasised. State government does have responsibilities in this area and, in this particular case, it certainly has to address this problem.

I have corresponded with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, making my views on this matter quite clear. While I have been in this place, I have been in constant contact with Ministers holding that portfolio concerning the situation at Redbank.

The need for a national facility has been a matter of debate for much of the past decade. Despite discussions between the Federal Government, States and Territories, and despite the best efforts of Ministers of the Federal Government, little has happened to promote the building of such a facility. Unfortunately, State governments as yet have not come up with a suitable site for a national storage facility, making planning of such a facility extremely difficult.

I believe that the time is long overdue for the Government to construct a national facility; however, a more cooperative attitude from the States is needed to get this project off the ground. It is important for the people of Esk and for the people of south-east Queensland that action on this matter occur immediately. The establishment of a national facility for radioactive waste will not overcome the need for State governments to maintain their own storage facilities, to collect waste before it can be transported to the national facility. It should be necessary, as envisaged, that the national facility will be open only periodically during the year.

I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on this Bill tonight, particularly on behalf of those people in the Esk area and to point out the concerns that they have when it comes to the storage of radioactive waste. I hope that the State Government will have its officers take another close look at this question of radioactive waste because it is one of considerable concern not just for the people of Esk and all those in the south-east corner but for the nation. All State governments probably are not doing the right thing in handling the matter of the storage of radioactive waste.

I suppose this Bill does highlight the need for government at all levels to address this very serious problem of the storage of waste, if little else. I know there are other aspects of the Bill, but I wanted to take the opportunity to highlight that particular point this evening. I really fear for those people and the concerns that they have for the whole industry in the local area as well as for the perceptions that are formed when these sorts of discussions get under way.

I hope that the Queensland State Government will take heed and have another serious look at the matter and also at the concerns that the people around the Esk area have. I also hope that it will encourage its colleagues at other levels of government and in other State governments to push for the establishment of a national facility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) that that really did sound suspiciously like 20 minutes of `not on my patch'. It is not really much good having a go at the State governments because, I remind him, this Government has also had 10 years to do something about the problem.

PARA.TAB: As the House has already been informed, the Opposition will not be opposing this Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill. Of course, what has really triggered it, as I think most of us understand, is that on 5 February this year the Land and Environment Court of New South Wales ordered that ANSTO be restrained from bringing radioactive waste from elsewhere onto its site at Lucas Heights for storage and that radioactive soil already brought from Victoria be removed within three years or upon establishment of a national low level radioactive waste repository. The case had been brought by the Shire of Sutherland in response to the recent arrival of 2,000 cubic metres of contaminated Victorian soil which was of CSIRO origin and in opposition to ANSTO's plans for storing 17 cubic metres of radioactive wastes from the Australian Defence Industries site at St Marys in Sydney.

Commendably, the Commonwealth has responded quickly to this court defeat by introducing this Bill which amongst other things seeks to render ANSTO immune from further New South Wales court orders similar to the one I just mentioned.

One reason for the Bill is that, because of the present lack of an acceptable site or sites, no national radioactive waste repository is expected to be operating for several years at least and as a consequence the Commonwealth wishes to be free to store its own and possibly other people's radioactive wastes at Lucas Heights as a temporary measure. Also, the Radiation Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council has completed and made available for public comment a draft code of practice and associated draft guidelines for the near surface disposal of radioactive waste in Australia. This code has been long in the making and is needed in an appropriate final form before any progress can be made, as I understand it, on siting a waste repository or repositories.

We support the legislation but I will make some remarks tonight about the more general subject in terms of the urgent need for permanent, safe acceptable sites and methods for radioactive waste disposal. The nature of the problem needs to be looked at first of all because not all radioactive waste is of the same dangerous level.

The definitions of radioactive waste are somewhat loose but there are basically four tiers. The first is very low level waste, which means radioactive waste which is of such low strength or `activity' and of sufficiently short half-life that disposal by the controlled release into the environment is permissible.

The second tier is low level waste mainly consisting of material of low activity and short half-life—by which we mean 30 years or less—which does not have to be specifically shielded while being handled and which contains only small amounts, if any, of long-lived alpha emitters.

The third tier is medium or intermediate level waste which contains higher activity material which requires shielding but not cooling during handling. Finally, there is high level radioactive waste which is of high or very high activity—in other words, spent fuel rods from nuclear reactors—and requires substantial shielding and cooling.

Australia holds radioactive wastes of all these types. For example, very low level waste consists typically of hospital residues of half-life less than five years, which includes radioisotopes used for measuring body functions—not those used, I might add, for treating cancers—and very low activity research isotopes from universities.

Low level materials make up the majority by volume of the remainder of Australia's radioactive waste. They consist of contaminated clothing, packaging, equipment, soil, mining wastes and so on. There is a significant proportion of medium level wastes consisting of spent radiotherapy sources, other spent sources such as level and moisture gauges, smoke detectors, radiography sources, liquids of various types, spent ion exchange resins and an unusually large proportion of radium 226, a long-lived alpha emitter which gives rise to radon, a gas, and its decay products which are the principal agents of lung cancer in uranium miners. The half-life of radium 226 is 1,600 years, so we are not talking about a short term problem. Most of the radium is present in older wastes made up of luminous paint, luminous watches, contaminated articles and so on.

Australia's high level wastes consist of spent reactor fuel, in particular the 1,500 or so spent fuel rods from ANSTO's main reactor. These are now stored in concrete in underground pits and are expected to be reprocessed in the United States for recovery of fissionable uranium or plutonium. But the United States may well require Australia to take back the highly radioactive wastes resulting from reprocessing.

It is estimated that about 90 per cent by volume of all radioactive wastes in Australia have arisen from Commonwealth activities and are stored at Commonwealth facilities such as Lucas Heights. This does not include wastes from uranium mining which are covered under a separate code of practice. Of the Commonwealth wastes, Lucas Heights is storing more than 3,000 cubic metres, while defence establishments hold approximately 250 cubic metres. About 60 to 70 cubic metres are generated in Australia each year.

Relative to other countries which use nuclear power and/or manufacture nuclear weapons, Australia puts out quite small volumes of waste. Britain, for example, generates a staggering 40,000 cubic metres per year of low level waste alone. France accumulates 30,000 cubic metres of such waste, the United States has hundreds of thousands of cubic metres awaiting disposal, while Japan is storing over one million drums of processed low level waste.

At present there are no facilities for final disposal of radioactive wastes in Australia, although the Western Australian Government has chosen a remote area for disposal of State wastes only. Nearly all of the 3,400 cubic metres or so of Australian stored radioactive wastes are therefore awaiting final disposal pending the location and development of an acceptable disposal site. There have been a number of problems in finding disposal sites, as the previous speaker mentioned. For example, in early 1978 the New South Wales Government began planning to remove about 3,000 tonnes of radioactive soil from Hunters Hill in Sydney to a remote rural site in order to decontaminate six house blocks. Although a disposal site at a disused gypsum mine was selected, word of the proposal spread quickly among the local Aboriginal people, graziers, local councillors and so on who all banded together and successfully lobbied against it.

The then Premier of New South Wales then applied to South Australia to have the New South Wales waste accepted at Radium Hill, an old uranium mine. However, because of public and union opposition, the then South Australian Premier turned down the request. It is interesting to note that all of the Hunters Hill material is still located in situ. In March 1983 a fire narrowly missed the Melbourne office building in whose basement radioactive waste had been stored since 1976. Of course, this only added to the concerns of public servants who were working nearby and those worried about the inadequate containers being used. Some of those containers were in fact old paint tins.

In resolving to relocate the wastes to a storage site outside of Melbourne, the Government in late 1985 chose a place called Dutson Downs near Sale over five other country sites. However, much local concern was generated for various reasons, including the presence of a nearby Royal Australian Air Force bombing range. Unions, local government and others were prominent in opposition. By February 1986 the decision to go ahead with that site was reversed after it was revealed that the State Government had been wrong on facts about the use of the bombing range. The waste is still located in government offices.

Western Australia, Tasmania and, as we have heard from the previous speaker, Queensland also have histories of difficulties with radioactive waste storage. In examining the breadth of interest groups and the arguments which have led to difficulties in siting these disposal sites, it is important to make the point, and it should be noted very carefully, that opposition is by no means restricted to greenie groups. The common rallying cry is much more likely to be `not in my backyard', as the previous speaker said.

Why are people so opposed to low level radioactive waste? Of course, there are a number of reasons: fear of radiation as invisible, scary and hard to understand; awareness of past disastrous accidents involving radiation, for example, Chernobyl; concern over the long half-life of some wastes; concern over a possible fall in property values near a disposal site; fear that a `temporary store' or State disposal site will become the national or permanent repository. Another reason may be that the very isolation of a rural site may lead to eventual entry by vandals, or conversely the site may be too close to housing, food production, tourism opportunities, and so on. There is also perhaps the belief that the wastes have arisen from the nuclear industry, nuclear energy or nuclear weapons production and the like, rather than from medicine, research and ordinary industry. The opposition may stem from radioactive wastes being brought a long distance from their source, from interstate or from overseas. People ask why it has to be sent so far away and feel that it must be particularly dangerous if it has to be sent so far away. There are also concerns about the transportation.

The various objections are mostly rational. They are shared by a number of interest groups—property owners, Aboriginal people, industry, local government, and so on, and they can be expected to surface on each occasion that a new disposal site is canvassed.

Partly in response to a 1975 NHMRC recommendation for a central repository for a longer lived radioactive wastes site, a Commonwealth-State consultative committee was set up as long ago as 1980 in order to coordinate policies. So we have been at it for some time. The present position is, unfortunately, that New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory have all refused to allow a national radioactive waste repository within their boundaries. Western Australia's position is not known in terms of the national situation, but its interest is very doubtful since it has set up the only radioactive waste disposal site in Australia at Mount Walton, a remote spot 130 kilometres north-west of Coolgardie. The first wastes will not be received until later this year but, significantly, the site is intended for State use only.

The political problems connected with radioactive waste disposal appear to have been underestimated generally and the parties have clearly reached a stalemate. Unfortunately, Australia has no clear guide from overseas as to the best method of disposal. Countries are using a variety of methods ranging from compacted earth trenches to vast underground caverns for their low level radioactive wastes. Inexplicably, there is no hard and fast international recommendation on disposal from, say, the International Atomic Energy Agency, which does not even define waste categories or acceptance criteria in its Safety Series publications. The national choice of methodology thus devolves to matters of cost, climate perhaps—is it wet or dry?—the degree of opposition to disposal, the volume of national wastes, and so on.

As I mentioned earlier, a draft code of practice for the near surface—by that, of course, we mean shallow ground—disposal of radioactive waste in Australia and draft guidelines on classification and disposal have been released for public comment. The code applies to medical, industrial and research wastes, contaminated materials and radioactive wastes arising from the processing of minerals but not to very low level wastes or uranium mining residue. Calculations on the safety of waste disposal have been based on limiting radiation exposure of site workers and members of the public according to current international recommendations.

Key points in the draft code and guidelines are that the disposal site or sites should preferably be located in arid areas of low population and institutional controls over each site should last for 200 years. I have to say that I believe these propositions are questionable over such a long time span with climate change and various other factors. The aridity of an area cannot be guaranteed; there may not always be a low population, of course, depending on developments; and institutional controls will change over a long period. So even 200 years really is only at the beginning of the end of the scale in terms of the periods that we need to talk about.

As a mining nation of importance, Australia may already possess disused mines which could accept large volumes of these types of wastes. The Australian decision to place virtually all of its radioactive wastes in shallow trenches dates back 10 years, or more than 10 years in some cases, when more thorough isolation of low and medium level radioactive wastes deep underground was rarely considered overseas. We just followed the overseas model and put them near the surface. The possibility of separating long lived alpha emitters from low level radioactive waste deserves perhaps more consideration. If adopted, public acceptability of permanent disposal might be considerably improved.

I conclude by saying that Australia's radioactive wastes are being temporarily stored at Lucas Heights and at dozens of other locations because there is no national repository for final disposal of the wastes. Since many of the present storage sites containing inadequately packaged wastes are located in urban areas and are almost full, the search for possible repository sites is becoming very urgent.

Regarding the present stalemate over siting, it is clear that each State and Territory does not wish to accept nationally generated radioactive waste. Even relocating internally generated waste has been difficult or unsuccessful, yet Australia is an arid continent of low population, large size and relatively stable geology and it should be, in many senses, more favoured than most countries in terms of its disposal options.

One possible solution to the siting dilemma perhaps is waste disposal on Commonwealth controlled or acquired land. This would be appropriate as most of the existing stored wastes are in fact of Commonwealth origin. If no Commonwealth land is suitable, the States and Territories should be encouraged, I suggest, to find their own sites, following the example of Western Australia.

I submit there needs to be a more serious study of public objections to siting attempts with a view to overcoming at least some of them. Although communities will never be enthusiastic over radioactive waste disposal near them, they could perhaps be reassured in a number of ways. We might, for example, think about Australia's stock and generation of radioactive waste, making the point to them that it is tiny by world standards, and is likely to remain so. Separation of long-life wastes for deep underground disposal may be an option. State or Territory sites would not necessarily accept interstate or overseas wastes. There would be strict limits on the life of each disposal site, plus careful monitoring. Australia's radioactive wastes are either of historical origin or are generated from socially useful activities, not including nuclear power. Substantial financial and other incentives may be offered to local government.

Finally, if the Australian States and Territories, apart from Western Australia, of course, continue to oppose a national site within their borders and if they do not agree to establish their own facilities, the responsibility for dealing with this problem—it cannot just be left up in the air—is clearly with the Government. It should get on with the job—not just react when some immediate problem crops up, as has happened with the Lucas Heights site—and sort it out so we will not need to find ourselves in this panic reaction mode that we are in today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight in support of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill. However, I must say that in researching this speech I found the issues arising from the Bill to be more complex than was at first obvious. I am pleased that when the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), who is now in the chair, and the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), made their speeches, they agreed that what arises from this particular amendment Bill is the urgent need for the establishment of a national, low level, radioactive waste repository which many believe should be the priority of this Government.

PARA.TAB: There is, as we realise, no nuclear industry as such in Australia. However, radioactive waste is produced as a result of research activities and the manufacturing of medical products from ores such as uranium and thorium. While this research and these products are beneficial to our Australian community, the waste resulting from them is not. For example, a large volume of uranium and thorium ores were mined at Fishermans Bend in Victoria between 1941 and 1965. The waste disposal practices of that operation, however, would not have been considered safe by today's standards. Consequently, over many years there has been a long process of contamination spreading throughout that particular area.

This problem of radioactive contamination was recognised in 1989 and was addressed by having the worst contaminated part of that area—predominantly the soil—transferred to the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation. It was stored there for treatment. In an article written in the Sydney Morning Herald at the time of that waste discovery, it was reported that the radioactivity on the Fishermans Bend site was 50 times above acceptable levels for the public.

The largest contaminated deposit found in the area covered about 400 square metres, which meant that about 500 tonnes of contaminated soil and waste product were under it. The news report of the day also stated that an unknown quantity of radioactivity had escaped from the site into the environment and was uncontrolled in its dispersal about the property. The article said that a government report found that `radioactivity had passed through the water drainage system and was present there'. According to that report, there had been no signs found on the property to indicate that it was radioactive and no documentation existed about that particular problem. It also stated that the site had been used by the CSIRO for research projects.

Can we be positive that the research projects being carried out today by ANSTO are so well documented and so safely executed that there will be no danger at all for future generations? Perhaps the CSIRO at the time thought it was taking all precautions necessary, and look what resulted from that. Although most of the radioactive waste stored at Lucas Heights is said to be relatively harmless, there is always a possibility, I believe, of an extreme example of a waste storage problem occurring. Among the waste presently stored at Lucas Heights is 17 cubic metres of solid low level radioactive wastes which consist of luminescent dial watches, compasses and buttons, thermionic valves and shield radium sources.

Radium, as has been stated here tonight, is the most dangerous nuclear substance. It has a very long half-life and is therefore going to be radioactive for thousands of years. Radium emits radon, a radioactive gas which contains particles that, when breathed in, causes lung cancer. These radium solids are stored in concrete and then in a drum at ANSTO. However, the radon gas can still leak through. Consequently, I have been informed that people who are living and working in that area are theoretically more exposed to radon gas and, therefore, may be more susceptible to contracting lung cancer. It is greatly ironic that products that are made from nuclear ores can help save the lives of our people suffering from cancer, yet the waste from the manufacturing of these products can cause cancer.

In February this year, Mr Justice Cripps of the Land and Environment Court of New South Wales ruled that ANSTO must remove the Fishermans Bend waste from Lucas Heights and no longer be allowed to store waste from the St Marys Australian Defence Industry Munitions Filling factory. This court order followed a legal battle between ANSTO and the Sutherland Shire Council over the storage and conditioning of radioactive waste at ANSTO's Lucas Heights research laboratories. The Council sought an order from the court restraining ANSTO from continuing to use the land at Lucas Heights for the purpose of storing radioactive waste. As a result of this court case, and according to the amendments contained in this Bill, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation is to become immune to specific classes of State and Territory laws and regulations which it is currently fully subject to.

The ANSTO Amendment Bill allows for the Fishermans Bend waste to be removed by the deadline of the court order. However, the Bill also allows for ANSTO to have immunity from certain State and Territory laws, essentially so that a court order such as the one mentioned cannot be passed on ANSTO again. It was found in the process of this court hearing that the land at Lucas Heights was under the authority at the time of the Council and, as such, it could only be used as a research station subject to conditions which may be imposed by the Council. According to the record of the hearing of Justice Cripps, the Council's consent was necessary if ANSTO intended to use the land for any purpose incidental or subsidiary to a research station, or if it was to be used for roads or utility installations. Use of the land for all other purposes is at this time, I understand, still prohibited. During the court hearing ANSTO was also forced to concede that to store radioactive waste for commercial gain was outside its legislative charter. According to Justice Cripps:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the Council has always opposed the use of the facility at Lucas Heights for the storage of low level nuclear wastes. However, it believed until about the middle of 1991 that, at law, it was not able to take any action to prevent it.
Justice Cripps also stated:

. . . there are no difficulties known to ANSTO in the management of the interim storage of the (radioactive waste) although . . . ANSTO itself acknowledges that there is always a possibility that the material might be spilled in certain circumstances such as in times of heavy rain with the result that contaminated material could escape.
Although it was accepted by the court that the radioactive waste had to be stored somewhere, Justice Cripps also noted:

. . . all relevant Ministers (Commonwealth and State) consider that the national repository be established as quickly as possible provided it is not established in the territory of their responsibility.

Justice Cripps concluded that as the court could not order any landowner in New South Wales to accept the waste that must be removed from Lucas Heights, a political solution would have to be found and the problem would have to be addressed. This Bill, therefore, allows for ANSTO to include in its functions the conditioning, storage and management of radioactive materials and radioactive waste.

PARA.TAB: Although the Bill provides for ANSTO to follow the court orders placed on it by Justice Cripps on 5 February this year—that is, not to accept any radioactive waste from the Australian Defence Industry at St Marys and to rid itself of the radioactive waste it is storing from Fishermans Bend within three years or when a national repository is established—it also allows for ANSTO to store other radioactive waste at Lucas Heights, if necessary, in the future, and to be immune from any further court action preventing this.

While this Bill allows for the problem of where to store radioactive waste in the short term until a national repository is established, it does not take into account the problem of what to do with the Fishermans Bend waste that must be removed or the radioactive waste that is already accumulating in Australia at the rate of approximately 100 cubic metres per year. Radioactive waste has been defined by the working party of the Radiation Health and Medical Research Council as `waste materials, either in solid or liquid form, either shielded or not which contain radioactive substances which are of no further current use'.

The working party described the health hazard to humans of radioactive waste in its draft code of practice for the near surface disposal of radioactive waste in Australia. I am pleased that it is available for public comment until 29 May this year. In the case of the radioactive waste stored at Lucas Heights, it is considered to be a low level risk to humans by the Safety Review Committee—a body established by the ANSTO Act 1987 and which comprises six members, the majority of whom are independent of ANSTO. According to a special report by the Safety Review Committee to the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) on the management of radioactive waste at Lucas Heights research laboratories:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the risks associated with the management and storage of radioactive waste at Lucas Heights Research Laboratories are substantially lower than those commonly accepted by members of the public for a wide range of activities.

The report states that if appropriate precautions are taken, the presence of radioactive wastes at Lucas Heights will not present a hazard to the general public, providing that the area remains undisturbed and all future direct residential development or construction is precluded in the immediate vicinity. The Safety Review Committee seems unconcerned also about the release of gases from the radioactive wastes at Lucas Heights. Its report states:

Releases of gaseous effluent at current levels are estimated to provide an annual radiation dose of only one per cent of the present annual limit recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council for members of the public.

The Committee is also satisfied that discharges of liquid effluent from the Lucas Heights research laboratories to the sewer meet the standards set under the New South Wales radioactive substances regulations and the standards for disposal of trade waste set by the Water Board, and that the effects of such discharges have been minimal. But I ask: how can we be certain that the effects of storing radioactive waste in that area continue to be safe? Can we be positive that in the future the people living in that area will not be affected in any way at all?

PARA.TAB: Although the Committee found ANSTO's laboratories at Lucas Heights to be storing the radioactive waste safely, it also stated that there was no place established for the safe disposal of this waste and that no non-Commonwealth radioactive waste should be stored at the Lucas Heights site. If carried out, this may not make a great deal of difference to ANSTO anyway. According to a briefing paper by the Parliamentary Library's science, technology and environment research service:

SPEECH.PARA: It is estimated that about 90% by volume of all . . . radioactive wastes in Australia have arisen from Commonwealth activities and are stored at Commonwealth facilities such as Lucas Heights.
The Safety Review Committee recommended:

. . . in the future, the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments begin . . . by identifying specific objectives and target dates for appropriate low and medium level radioactive waste repositories and that they allocate sufficient priority and resources to achieve those objectives and targets.

According to an article in the March 1992 edition of Australian Environment Review, the absence of a national repository for nuclear waste is a major problem, particularly for ANSTO which has 10,000-odd drums of radioactive waste stacked under a tarpaulin in its grounds at Lucas Heights. ANSTO has to worry not only about the radioactive waste already being stored by it, but also about the waste that is continually produced as a result of its research. The report that I have referred to states:

The fact that small stockpiles of low-level radioactive waste like these exist in spots around Australia is not the issue at stake. It is the greater problem of what to do with them. Everyone is agreed that a national radioactive waste repository is the best answer, but the (Not in My Backyard) syndrome has turned what seems a logical solution into a political nightmare.

As honourable members realise, ANSTO has been given three years to remove the waste it is storing from Fishermans Bend but, according to Dr David Cook, the Executive Director of ANSTO, there is nowhere for it to go. Dr Cook is reported to have said that he believes it is unlikely that a national repository will be found within three years, yet there is nowhere else for that waste to go. He is also quoted as saying:
The case has focused minds in the political arena on the fact that decisions, however unpalatable in the political sense, have to be made, because we are generating this kind of material.
According to the article:

Some states, like Western Australia and Queensland, are looking at establishing state repositories to store the waste, but Dr Cook believes this is short-sighted. The amount of radioactive waste that Australia produces, mostly from the use of radioisotopes in medicine and industry, is too small to warrant a multitude of storage sites.
According to the brief on radioactive waste disposal in Australia prepared by the science, technology and environment research service:

One reason for the Bill is that, because of the present lack of an acceptable site or sites, no national radioactive repository is expected to be operating for several years at least. As a consequence, the Commonwealth wishes to be free to store its own—and possibly other—radioactive waste at Lucas Heights as a temporary measure.

That briefing paper defines low level radioactive waste as mainly material of low activity with a short half-life of 30 years or less, which does not have to be specially shielded while being handled and which contains only small amounts, if any, of long-lived alpha emitters. It states that medium level waste:

. . . contains higher activity material which requires shielding but not cooling during handling. Long-lived alpha-emitters can be present, usually up to a set level. High level radioactive waste is of high to very high activity and requires substantial shielding and cooling.
According to the same brief, Australia holds radioactive waste of all of these types. However, it states:

There are at present no facilities for final disposal of radioactive waste in Australia, although Western Australia has chosen a remote area for disposal of State wastes only. Nearly all of the 3400 cubic metres or so of Australian stored radioactive wastes are therefore awaiting final disposal, pending the location and development of an acceptable disposal site or sites.

A number of States, including New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland, have had difficulties in finding suitable storage sites for radioactive waste, again according to the science, technology and environment research service. All these States have been faced with trying to find a site to store large amounts of radioactive waste in an unexpectedly, so they stated, short time. In every case, community and local government opposition to having a storage site for nuclear waste in their backyard has been the major barrier.

PARA.TAB: According to the briefing paper, there are many lobby groups against the storage of radioactive waste which have various objections, most of which it says are rational and can be expected to rise every time a new disposal site is suggested. The paper states:

SPEECH.PARA: The present position, as revealed in February 1992, is that NSW, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory have all refused to allow a national radioactive waste repository within their boundaries. Western Australia's position is not known, but its interest is very doubtful since it has set up the only radioactive waste disposal site in Australia . . . Significantly, the site is intended for State use only.
According to the same paper:

As a mining nation of importance, Australia may already possess disused mines which could accept large volumes of alpha-emitting wastes. The Australian decision to place virtually all of its radioactive wastes in shallow trenches dates back ten or more years, when more thorough isolation of low and medium level radioactive wastes deep underground was rarely considered overseas . . . Since many of the present storage sites contain inadequately packaged wastes, are located in urban areas and are almost full, the search for possible repository sites is becoming urgent.

The issue of finding a safe site for a national radioactive waste repository, and establishing it before the final date of the particular court order comes into effect, I believe should now be of paramount importance.

PARA.TAB: I was particularly pleased that the Opposition is not opposing this Bill because I, like other members of parliament, have full confidence in the Minister in the adoption of the amendments to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill 1992 does three fundamental things: firstly, it continues the expansion of the Lucas Heights facility as a storage for radioactive materials and waste; secondly, it gives the organisation immunity from State laws; and, thirdly, it expands the charter for privatisation. Fundamentally, it entrenches ANSTO for the long term future and it does it by retrospective legislation.

PARA.TAB: On all counts, in my view, this Bill should not be passed. It sets up directions for the long term future of the nuclear industry in this country and it affects some hundreds of thousands of people who live in the Sydney area. What we really have is a knee-jerk reaction to a decision of the Land and Environment Court passed in February this year and we have a stamping on the legitimate concerns of the people of the Sutherland shire. I remind the House that the Sutherland shire has one of the largest populations of any shire in Australia. It is actually much greater than the Northern Territory.

This Bill should have at least gone before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. A foolish short term decision was taken many years ago to establish Lucas Heights in what was then bushland around the Sydney area. It was totally predictable at that time that the future population growth and the urban sprawl would eventually surround the facility but that was ignored; just as what is being ignored today is the fact that the Sydney urban conurbation will extend in 30 years from north of Newcastle to south of Nowra and will consist of about seven million people. This facility is absolutely in the centre of that urban conurbation. I think that if honourable members were honest they would agree—as I am quite sure the majority of Australians would agree—that is about the last possible place to put a storage facility for nuclear waste, given all the problems that have been gone over many times in this House, such as transport of nuclear waste and the problems of terrorism.

For over a decade, this House has been debating the fact that we need a national repository for waste. This Bill tells the public that we were not really serious; in fact, we are entrenching it at Lucas Heights forever. I think it is quite dishonest of any honourable member to pretend that this is only a temporary storage facility. Over recent years, there has been a constant expansion of the facility, the bringing in of nuclear waste from Victoria at Fishermans Bend and St Marys. No reasonable person, knowing that history, could not believe that Lucas Heights is now the permanent national repository for nuclear waste.

Given the privatisation and the many calls for Australia to be a repository for the world's nuclear waste, the financial incentive to expand the Lucas Heights facility is quite overwhelming. If the Government wanted to devise a method of building public hostility to Lucas Heights, it did so with this Bill. It stamps on the New South Wales planning laws, privatises the facility to create the incentive to expand it, and expands it in the Bill itself. It is no wonder that the Sutherland shire is full of rumours about the facility, and the fears are going to get greater. It is no wonder that the Sutherland Shire, in support of the local community, has already spent so much money. It is now being stamped on by this House. The Sutherland Shire Environment Centre states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Court action taken by Sutherland Shire Council is the only action taken against ANSTO in 34 years of operation, and was supported by the local community. . . . this Bill is an over-reaction to the N.S.W. Land and Environment Court's decision.
Clause 5 of the Bill completely destroys the rights of N.S.W., and particularly Sutherland Shire citizens to control their environment.
Or have any say in it for that matter. It continues:
It would allow the Federal Government to build another reactor at Lucas Heights and remove the right of citizens to prevent it.
It would allow any type of industry to be established in the Technology Park.
It would allow any type of radioactive materials and waste to be transported through the State and Sutherland Shire; and any amount of gaseous and liquid discharges could leave the site.
It would allow any activity to take place on the site, e.g. enrichment or waste treatment.

When the ANSTO Act was passed in 1987 local people gained some confidence that the activities of ANSTO would be curtailed and that less secrecy would prevail. This confidence will be destroyed if the Bill is passed.
If ANSTO is a Research Establishment, as it claims, it should behave like one. No other scientific establishment seeks to flout State Planning and Environment laws.

The truth is that none of us knows where the nuclear industry is headed. Therefore, none of us knows the future for this site. No amount of public relations exercises and smooth talking about minimal risks is going to appease the Sutherland Shire and the residents. If we want nuclear research and the associated waste dump, we have to find another site.

PARA.TAB: The concept of excluding the Commonwealth from State laws, particularly in planning and environment, is essentially a fascist one. It tells people that there is one law for the Government and another one for the people. It tells developers that all they need, if they want to get anywhere, is a mate in Canberra and they can override whatever State laws stand in their way. On top of all that we make it retrospective. In view of what has been said in this House about retrospective legislation over the years, I really do not know how the Opposition can support this Bill.

The push to privatisation and commercialisation of Commonwealth bodies generally, and this one in particular, will be a ready-made way to subvert the State law. We can be sure that we are going to have many more controversies in the future. We are seeing in this Bill the same short term expediency and the `end justifies the means' philosophy as the Greiner-Metherell affair in New South Wales—and it is going to be equally condemned and it is going to be equally futile in the long run.

The fact that I am the only speaker against this Bill in this House is a testimony, of course, to the centralised control here that stops members speaking their own minds or even representing their electorates. There is not a single member of this House who would not be on his feet, were it not for party control, if this facility were in his electorate. If there is, I would very much like him to identify himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to identify myself to the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack). The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill arises out of the actions of the Sutherland Shire Council in going beyond its area of responsibility. The Commonwealth Government has an overriding responsibility to ensure that nuclear material and nuclear waste is safely stored until such time as we find a permanent repository. This legislation merely enshrines that and stops the local, often ill-informed and emotional view from taking over at the expense of the entire nation.

PARA.TAB: As many people have said, this Bill underlines the need for long term storage of waste in Australia. We have to look at waste in several categories. Certainly, a lot of the low level waste would be much better incinerated and reduced to ashes; in that way the volume would be reduced. While there would be a concentration of the radioactivity, there would be only a very small amount of material, which could then be safely contained.

Radioactivity is such an emotional topic these days that it is very hard to get a logical debate. At Windscale some years ago there was a small leakage of alpha-emitting radiation. The leak was detected by the plant, which made efforts to send it back to the plant; there was a spillage and it escaped into the ocean. Hysteria was such that there was talk of the whole ocean becoming radioactive and there were reports that the beach was twice as radioactive as it was before. This may have been true, of course, but we are talking from a very small base. I remember pictures of people clustered on the granite rocks at the end of the beach making a wild dash across the beach into the sea and then a mad dash back across the beach rather than come in contact with the radioactivity on the beach. The joke, of course, was that the granite rocks on which they were standing were many times more radioactive than the beach itself.

I might add that when we opened this Parliament House I made a point of going over it with a scintillometer. This Parliament House is about three times as radioactive as the old Parliament House. I notice that some of my colleagues on the Left who were anti-uranium did not elect to stay out of the House. I guess the attraction of the rather more splendid accommodation than that in the old one was just too hard to resist.

My electorate is ideal for the storage of high-level nuclear waste. I am very happy to have high-level nuclear waste stored in my electorate. The Western Australian Government has looked at a site in my electorate and this site is ideal for the storage of nuclear waste or chemical waste. It has all the requirements. It is a low rainfall area and it has internal draining—that is, no water runs out of the area at all. Where underground water exists—and it is very rare—it is extremely salty. When I say `extremely salty', we are talking about many hundreds of thousands of parts per million—many times saltier than the sea. This is an ideal place for the storage of waste.

My own view is that there should be a repository in my electorate for chemical waste and perhaps for low level waste. Such low level waste may arise, for example, from the treatment of mineral sands. I might add that this demonstrates the appalling ignorance we get on the subject of radiation. The Conservation Foundation, that group of Commonwealth-funded frauds that causes so much angst in the community, went to the State Government and said, `Look, you must stop these wicked French mining these mineral sands in Australia and taking them over to France; they are taking all our jobs with them; they will take out the thorium and they will make bombs'—which, of course, is technically possible, but economic madness.

While not swallowing the thorium line, the Government thought that they were certainly taking jobs out of the country, so they said, `Yes'. The Government went and said to the wicked French, `Look, we want you to process this material in Australia; we want to keep the jobs in Australia', to which the French said, `Well, as a matter of fact we are looking to build a new plant; our plant in France at La Rochelle is running at about 110 per cent capacity; America is approaching 100 per cent capacity. We need a new one and it is either Australia or Japan; frankly, we would rather deal with Australia'. It started very well.

I know the French went down to the south of Perth to inquire about getting some land. They asked the Government what the land would be worth, and the Government said, `A ballpark figure would probably be $350,000 to $400,000', to which the French said, `Are you talking in acres or hectares?'. They had made similar inquiries about land in France. When they were assured this was for a farm, they were astounded and decided that they really had made the best decision. No sooner had they started, however, than back came the conservationists to the Government and said, `You must make these wicked French take the radioactivity with them if they process in Australia; they cannot process here and leave this wicked thorium lying around'. Their agenda, as usual, was simply to stop development.

That led to a lot of problems. I readily agreed to have that stored in my electorate. But, in the end, the price of rare earth deteriorated and Rhone Polonc simply walked away. It walked away because it was never given guidelines which it could say that it could meet or could not meet. This whole emotional debate is often history.

But we in Australia have a responsibility. Governments of both persuasions in this House have neglected the nuclear industry. Despite the brave words of the Liberal Party when it was in power under Malcolm Fraser, with a total mandate, it did absolutely nothing. It would not even let existing mines sign new contracts. That was left to the incoming Labor Government to do. That was the golden opportunity to change things around, but it was never taken. Even so, with the small part of the world's trade that we do get, we supply a lot of uranium to Japan. It seems to me to be arrant nonsense to be suggesting that we should say to Japan, `You must store your high level wastes on your little island riven by earthquakes', and pretend that that is safer than bringing it back to Australia and storing it safely.

In Australia, we have a process developed by Dr Ringwood at the ANU, and developed further by ANSTO, for the containment of high level waste. I refer, of course, to synroc. Synroc actually locks the nuclear activity up into the atomic lattice and is virtually unleachable. It is many times safer than borro silica glass. I am not saying that borro silica glass is not safe; in actual fact, I think it is probably safe enough. Certainly, the new iron silicates that the French are dealing with are better than the borro silicates. But even so, the radioactivity retention of synroc is many times better.

The proposal for the storage of high level waste was simply that it would be mixed up with this artificial mixture which, when heated under pressure, makes a rock-like material. Therefore, it got its name of synroc. This would be then encased in stainless steel and lowered into bore holes drilled in the ground. I think these bore holes were to be something in the order of two foot ten inches wide—to use Christian measurements—and they were about one kilometre deep. The idea was to put one of those containers in, and backfill it with 100 metres of high yielding clay. When we got close to the surface—when I say `close to the surface', I mean perhaps 300 or 400 metres—we backfilled the whole lot with crushed sedimentary rock. That would be incarcerated in a geologically stable area for all time. Australia would have the best technology, the best geology and the best geography for storing this high level waste.

It is interesting to note that, on 1,000 square kilometres of land, if we put these bore holes in at 100 metre centres, by the time we got to the end we could go back and start again because the decay cycle of that high level waste would be over. That is assuming that the longest lasting ingredient was plutonium.

There is a lot of misunderstanding about radioactivity. People say, `Shock, horror! Plutonium glass has a half-life of 240,000 years', and it does. The reason it has such a long half-life is that it is not very radioactive. The very radioactive and the fissionable materials have very short half-lives; they burn themselves out very quickly. That is where the really dangerous elements occur.

I was touring one nuclear facility. At the end of the tour, the scientist fished into his pocket, pulled out a lump of metal, slapped it on my hand and he said, `That is our end product. That is plutonium metal'. I noticed that it was quite warm, and I did not know whether this was from body heat or the heat of radioactive decay. So I asked him and he said, `That is the radioactive decay'. I said to him, `Are you not a little concerned having this ensconced in your pocket around the family jewels?'. He said, `No. I have it wrapped up in gladwrap and there is 100 per cent prevention'. Gladwrap was preventing the escape of alpha.

TALK.START.PARA: —What else do you use gladwrap for?

—I am told that they have some novel uses for it in some of the schools. Alpha particles are completely contained by gladwrap. Of course, alpha is the most dangerous type of radioactivity that we had to deal with because of its propensity to escape into the atmosphere and attach itself to other things which get inhaled. Alpha is the main cause of lung cancer. Technically, I am told it is the exclusion of a helium nucleus—a very large, slow moving part—without any great penetrating power. But if we inhale it into our lungs, it can sit there for 20 years and may just give us lung cancer.

PARA.TAB: I digress from the Bill for a moment which, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will notice that I have kept very closely to. The health industry tells us that one of the reasons that there is a high incidence of lung cancer in Cornwall is cigarette smoking. The reality is that it is much more likely to be as a result of all the yuppies buying the old miners' cottages and double glazing them, preventing any ventilation and subjecting themselves to very high doses of radon and radon's daughter products which are emitted naturally from the granite in that area. I would say, almost certainly, that is why that part of the UK has the very highest incidence of lung cancer. It has nothing or very little to do with cigarettes. But then why should we spoil a good story when there is so much funding going to that area.

If we were to take back just Japan's high level waste and store it safely and properly in Australia, it would probably be a $2 billion industry. I have said that I am quite happy to have the storage in my electorate. I think, however, we would be much better off to look at places somewhere to the west of Broken Hill. With all the goodwill in the world, Broken Hill is looking down the barrel of being one of the world's great ghost towns. The ore-body has a finite life. It is going to be worked out and there is going to be nothing for these people in Broken Hill to do. I will warrant that, rather than walk away from that town, the Barrier Council will sit down and discuss rationally and constructively the idea of a repository for nuclear waste somewhere in the vicinity of the Hill.

I am told that there are areas of ultra basic rock in that area which are geologically very stable and would be ideal for this sort of purpose. Of course, when Broken Hill goes down the tube, Port Pirie follows it. It has very good infrastructure; it has a very good railway line. It would seem to me that one would be much better off ridding the people of Port Pirie from that very dangerous lead that emits from the smelter there and replacing it with relatively less dangerous nuclear waste. It would seem to me that the logical thing to do would be to have Port Pirie as the gateway port for the disposal of high level waste. However, if it does not want it, as I have said I am very happy to have it in my electorate and have the hundreds of thousands of jobs in Western Australia that the nuclear industry, if properly addressed, will create in Australia.

It always amazes me that the Left of my own Party is so emotionally involved in this subject. This has become an absolute cause for it when it offers a potential for so much employment in Australia. One must ask why this has come about. The policy of the Labor Party prior to 1976 was to process, store and reprocess uranium. That was our policy in 1976 and we changed it. We changed it overnight on a whim. I must admit that in those days, having read all the anti-propaganda, I was convinced that this was a diabolical commodity and I actively tried to get that policy changed, and I was successful. Having done that, I then decided that my contribution was not enough and I should go to France and campaign in France. I rightly observed that it did not matter what one did in Australia, in the world scheme of things we are irrelevant. We really had to stop it in France.

So off to France I went. With my wife interpreting, I harangued crowds in supermarkets and spoke around France in picture theatres. I might add that I spoke eloquently, but in English that probably was not well understood, despite my wife's translations. However, while I was there I also decided to look at the nuclear industry and realised what a fool I was making of myself. I was completely wrong, so I changed my mind. When I am wrong, I find it best to change my mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —So will you now vote for Hawke?

—I think that is another question which I will elaborate on sometime soon. It is a good policy and I wish that many of my other colleagues would do this. I know—and I have discussed it with people in the party who are locked into an ideological position on this—that it is not just in this party; it is in the Opposition parties as well. People have these emotional positions which are a mixture of fact and fiction and a substantial amount of the NIMBY disease.

PARA.TAB: This Bill is an attempt by the Government to try to codify and make safe the proper containment of waste. There has never been any suggestion that anything unsafe was being practised at ANSTO. That has never been suggested—not even by the Sutherland Shire. It seems to me that the Government is making sure that one facility in Australia has the technology, the understanding and the facilities to store this waste, and that it is simply being empowered to do so by this legislation.

I do not think we are ever going to see—as the honourable member for North Sydney thinks—anything other than basic research at Lucas Heights. The facility lends itself to research and, frankly, not to much else. But we do have to address this problem. I suggest that the Commonwealth Government and other States of Australia, having conspicuously failed to do this themselves, should seriously approach the Western Australia Government with a view to using facilities which the Western Australian Government has identified. The Western Australian Government may, like most State governments, pander to its own constituency; but I believe that if the financial inducements were sufficient, the Western Australian Government would expand its facilities to look at taking the Australian waste.

We need only one storage facility of this kind in Australia. I think that Western Australia could easily accommodate low and medium level waste and could also handle a lot of chemical waste and the destruction of chemical waste. As I have said, the storage of high level waste is a different thing altogether. I believe that synroc is the process to use. I believe that the Government should show a little intestinal fortitude and have the guts to really tackle the nuclear industry head on: to look at the enormous number of jobs that can develop in Australia and to look at the contribution it can make to safe storage of high level wastes in the world.

It really is nonsense to suggest that it would be better for us to let the Japanese dump it in the ocean, as they invariably will when the problem becomes too pressing. Clearly, it is in our interests and in the interests of the world generally to take back that waste and store it properly and safely under controlled conditions, for which we, as a nation, would be well and truly compensated.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—First of all, I thank all honourable members who participated in the debate: you, Mr Deputy Speaker; the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran); the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent); the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio); the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack); and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I also thank the Opposition for its support of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill. I listened to all of the speeches carefully and generally found them to be thoughtful and constructive, although not universally so.

PARA.TAB: The central issue that emerged from the debate is that while State and local government authorities have their responsibilities and while the Commonwealth will continue to cooperate, consult and report in an open manner, as it has in the past, the principal responsibility in this matter is with the Commonwealth. Accordingly, the Commonwealth seeks specific immunities for the operation of ANSTO.

The comments on the amendments seemed to turn to two issues. The first issue is the suggestion that the amendments will allow the Lucas Heights research laboratory site to be used as a national radioactive waste dump. I say categorically, as I said in my second reading speech, that the Government has no intention of permitting Lucas Heights to become a national radioactive waste dump. This is no more clearly demonstrated than by the specific exclusion of the Fishermans Bend waste in the amendments. After 5 February 1995, consistent with the decision of the New South Wales Land and Environment Court earlier this year, it must be removed.

Further, the Bill incorporates a requirement for specific regulations which, of course, are subject to disallowance by the Parliament—so much for the alleged fascist legislation—if ANSTO is to continue to condition, manage or store any wastes which are not generated by its activities.

The Government recognises that a permanent national radioactive waste repository must be established. My colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has been actively seeking the cooperation of the State governments in locating areas for a suitable site. In the spirit of the bipartisanship which has characterised much of this debate, my colleagues in the Opposition might encourage their colleagues in New South Wales to actually respond positively to the correspondence of September last year from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

While such a site is being identified, wastes such as that already at Lucas Heights must be stored safely. The Government has ordered a report identifying all possible options for the safe interim storage of the Fishermans Bend waste and the St Marys ADI waste—after February 1995 in the case of Fishermans Bend and, of course, before that in the case of St Marys.

The second issue that has been raised is that of States' rights and the ability of Sutherland Shire citizens to control their environment. As I hope my second reading speech made clear, the granting of immunity for Commonwealth bodies from State and local government laws and regulations is nothing new. Similar clauses were included in recent legislation which established Australian Defence Industries and the Civil Aviation Authority. The predecessor of ANSTO—the Australian Atomic Energy Commission—also had crown protection from State and Territory laws. It was never the Commonwealth's intention that ANSTO should be fully subject to State laws, and neither should it be.

As Australia's centre for nuclear science and technology expertise, ANSTO undertakes what is essentially a national role in the effective development and implementation of the Commonwealth's nuclear safeguards, uranium export, non-proliferation and nuclear arms control policies. These are not matters which can be subject to the approval of individual local councils or State governments.

Regarding the question of the safety of local residents, ANSTO's safety record has never been seriously challenged. If one reads the judgment of the court, this was, in fact, underlined and reinforced by what Judge Cripps had to say in his summing up. The ANSTO is required to meet rigorous standards and it cooperates closely with the State Government authorities in doing so. In fact, the amendments underline the Government's commitment to the safe operation of the Lucas Heights facility by strengthening the independence of the Nuclear Safety Bureau.

Those opposing this Bill should also consider carefully the implications for public welfare if the Bill were to be withdrawn or defeated. The ANSTO would not be able to deal adequately with incidents involving spills of radioactive substances or packages damaged in transport. The provision of nuclear medicine services would be severely curtailed. The number of sites where radioactive waste is stored in Australia would increase dramatically, as would the volume of material stored there, as ANSTO would no longer be able to receive spent source material for recycling, treatment or storage. The New South Wales Government, for example, has relied on this service to reduce substantially the volume of material at its radioactive waste store at Lidcombe.

It is precisely for these national interest reasons that the Commonwealth must retain control of facilities such as the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories. The Commonwealth has no intention of allowing Lucas Heights to become a de facto national radioactive waste repository nor, however, does it intend to hand control of the reactor over to a local council, a State government department or a State Minister.

I think a number of particular comments addressed to the chamber by the honourable member for North Sydney need a little additional comment, although I believe I have addressed the bulk of his remarks. This Bill does not provide, as he suggested, for the continuous expansion of Lucas Heights as a place for storage, or for its establishment as a permanent national repository. As I have pointed out, the Bill requires the removal of the Fishermans Bend waste.

The Bill hardly stamps on State law. I believe it seeks to establish the appropriate balance of power for the Commonwealth to fulfil its responsibilities in this matter. I was amused to hear the honourable member for North Sydney equating the interests of the Government of New South Wales with those of the people of New South Wales. I would have thought the evidence in recent times would have been to the contrary. Without infringing on the spirit of bipartisanship, which has been a feature of this debate, I would shudder to think that one would consider handing over control of matters nuclear to the current New South Wales environment Minister.

The Bill does not, as the honourable member for North Sydney suggests, pave the way for the construction of a replacement reactor at Lucas Heights. If the honourable member for North Sydney takes the trouble to read my statement of last Thursday, when I tabled the ASTEC report on national facilities, he will see that a lengthy and exhaustive process of inquiry will be undertaken before any decision is taken about the construction of a replacement for HIFAR, let alone where that replacement reactor might be constructed.

Finally, on the question of retrospectivity, I inform the honourable member for North Sydney that at present on the site there is non-ANSTO generated waste which was not subject to the decision of the court. Were these amendments to fail, the storage of this material would be illegal. That is the reason for the retrospectivity. I hope those comments satisfy the honourable member for North Sydney. It was evident to me that he had not read the Bill as thoroughly as he might have. I know he is a person who will now go back and read the legislation, the explanatory memorandum and the supporting material and perhaps get a better grasp of it before falling into the trap of generating cheap but inaccurate headlines.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Free) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was some understandable jocularity associated with the result of the division on the second reading motion. Honourable members who have been participating in or listening to this debate will know what an unmitigated stunt the calling of that division was by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack) and the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary). Anybody who listened to the contribution of the honourable member for North Sydney will know immediately that he has neither read the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill or the judgment of the New South Wales Land and Environment Court delivered in February which necessitated the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The cliche ridden hyperbole which led the honourable member for North Sydney to describe it as fascist legislation is utterly disgraceful. He never once addressed the major issues which arose out of that court case. There was just a string of endless cliches put together. In fact, some of those cliches were very familiar to me. I could tell the honourable member for North Sydney who within the Parliamentary Library wrote his speech, and I will certainly mention the name to him later. It is not as if he came up with anything original.

The honourable member for North Sydney ignored a number of aspects that are vital to understanding this legislation. It can only be understood if the judgment of the New South Wales Land and Environment Court is read. Firstly, that judgment found that there is no safety issue associated with the storage or transportation of radioactive waste or nuclear waste to the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories from the Australian Defence Industries site at St Marys near Penrith or with the transportation of 2,000 tonnes of contaminated soil from CSIRO at Fishermans Bend to Lucas Heights. Let us put that to rest once and for all—no safety issue associated with ANSTO's handling of the material or its storage. In fact, the judge expressly declared ANSTO to be the most appropriate authority with the greatest expertise and experience to handle this waste.

Secondly, the honourable member for Sydney ignores totally Crown immunity. As the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) pointed out in his second reading speech and again in his reply, we have a number of Commonwealth agencies which have immunity from State and Territory laws, such as the Civil Aviation Authority and Australian Defence Industries.

This is a national facility. It does not belong to the Sutherland Shire Council nor to the New South Wales Government. Who are we kidding? It has always been the practice of ANSTO to abide by the New South Wales planning and environment laws. The Minister has given undertakings that it will continue to do so. The judgment of the New South Wales Land and Environment Court was that the principal Act governing ANSTO defined it as a research agency. In later years, because ANSTO has sought out commercial opportunities, it has gone beyond the role specifically defined for it by the legislation; therefore, it did not have Crown immunity.

Given that, the honourable member for North Sydney has to answer the question: what do we do with the waste? No-one else in Australia can deal with it. What do we do with the ADI and CSIRO waste? What do we do with the industrial and medical isotopes? What happens if there is a breakage in medical equipment? It has to be transported to ANSTO for repair. Under the judgment of the court it cannot even be transported to ANSTO. What do we do with all of that?

That is exactly why this is a stunt by the honourable member for North Sydney and the honourable member for Wills. We have the sight of the honourable member for Wills looking like a rabbit caught by the headlights of a motor vehicle, not knowing what he has done. If the honourable member for North Sydney has not read the legislation or the judgment which led to the legislation, we can also be quite certain that the honourable member for Wills has not read it.

I have no doubt at all that this House will be subjected to a number of divisions of this sort from the two honourable members, all designed for one purpose only: to align themselves with the weird and the wonderful who are easily persuaded that they are being represented by these honourable members. When the honourable member for North Sydney calls this Bill fascist legislation and something of a conspiracy by the major political parties, I for one will not tolerate it.

This legislation has been carefully thought out by both the Government and the coalition. We have stated at great length the reasons why we have accepted the legislation. Yet the honourable member for North Sydney totally ignored any of those complex or compelling reasons for the legislation. So it is really up to the honourable member for North Sydney; if he is genuine and sincere, he can tell us: if the waste is not stored at ANSTO and treated and managed by ANSTO until a nuclear and radioactive waste repository can be developed, as the court said—this will be new information, of course—by 5 February 1995, what do we do with it in the meantime?

No doubt the honourable member hopes that the novelty of the first division called by the two Independents, which saw the Government and the Opposition total 128 against two, will gain him some publicity. No doubt the gullible media, which give the honourable member for North Sydney and the honourable member for Wills more than their fair share of publicity, will fall for it. But the truth is that on any examination their contribution to this debate is certainly not worth the slightest bit of attention. The way the honourable member for North Sydney wraps himself in treacle-like smugness I cannot accept. I do not mind being lectured by Mother Theresa or the Dalai Lama, but I will be blowed if I am going to accept it from somebody whom I regard as a total political opportunist.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pity that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), has to resort to character assassination arguments on this issue. For him to pretend that there is no public concern not only in this country but around the world over nuclear storage is quite ridiculous. To have to resort to character assassination arguments to deal with what is genuine concern by the Sutherland Council and the people who live around that area is unacceptable.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that for the last decade we have been talking about finding an alternative site and now we move into a situation of privatisation and expansion of the facilities. How can any reasonable person believe that the Government is really serious about finding an alternative site? We all know in a practical world how difficult it will be to find an alternative site. But, as I said previously, given the expansion of the population of Sydney, we have to do so and it is urgent. For the honourable member to just stand up and character assassinate and trivialise the arguments is really beneath him.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.
