DEBATE.TITLE: REMUNERATION AND ALLOWANCES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 2 April, on motion by Mr Baldwin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Remuneration and Allowances Legislation Amendment Bill specifically deals with the creation of a new salaries structure for the restructured Industrial Relations Commission, certain recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal and certain salary proposals for university vice-chancellors and might in other circumstances have passed by without very much public notice. But any opportunity that the Government may have thought it would have of this legislation passing by without any kind of public notice, any kind of press speculation or any kind of political interest was, of course, completely shattered on 14 April this year when a man by the name of Mr Ken Turbet tendered his resignation as a member of the Industrial Relations Commission.

PARA.TAB: It is worth while if I read a few paragraphs of Mr Turbet's letter to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). It is a very instructive letter and it exposes—from the vantage point of a man who certainly does not share my political philosophy—some deep-seated tensions and hypocrisies inside the broad labour movement regarding the conduct of industrial relations in Australia. In his letter Mr Turbet writes:

SPEECH.PARA: I respond to your letter to the President, Mr Justice Maddern, dated 8 April 1992, by advising of my intention to tender my resignation, as a Commissioner of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, to the Governor General with effect from 10 May 1992.
This is really the essence of the importance of the Turbet resignation; he then goes on to say:

The reasons for my resignation after 14 years as a Commission member, which was preceded by 16 years service to the trade union movement and 20 years membership of the Australian Labor Party are three-fold.
This is the coup de grace:
Firstly, the Government cannot be relied upon to keep to its word.

Let me say that again: `Firstly, the Government cannot be relied upon to keep to its word.' One will not find many people on this side of the House dissenting from that proposition. But it is an extraordinarily apposite and relevant proposition, especially coming from a man who has devoted all of his adult life to the service of the labour movement and to the maintenance of an industrial relations system which we on this side of the House are determined to alter and alter permanently so far as the future of this country is concerned.

PARA.TAB: Mr Turbet then goes on to detail a current example of how the Government could not be relied upon to keep its word. He speaks of the recommendations of the Gleeson Committee on the Remuneration Tribunal and he details that Mr Gerry Gleeson, the former head of the Premier's Department—a man who was the closest adviser that Neville Wran had when he was the Labor Premier of New South Wales—recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government should only seek to disallow a remuneration determination of the Tribunal if extraordinary circumstances arise.
To this the Cabinet said:
The need to maintain the independence of the Remuneration Tribunal is recognised and the Government accepts that it should only seek to disallow determinations in exceptional circumstances.
Mr Turbet goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: Yet the first determination you receive from the Remuneration Tribunal concerning the AIRC following this announcement of policy you reject. There are no "extraordinary or exceptional circumstances" surrounding the Remuneration Tribunal's decision. There are, in fact, 15 pages of detailed reasoning supporting the decision. The word of the Government in the form of an official policy statement just wasn't worth the paper it was written on.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, we have a Labor man of 40 years saying that a Government statement was not worth the paper it was written on. The letter goes on to detail very serious allegations against the Minister. Mr Turbet says:

. . . my . . . most compelling reason for resigning is your Government's total lack of understanding of and respect for the Constitutional requirements of Section 51. . . of the Constitution. There have been five referenda directed at altering this provision. All have failed. The Industrial Relations power is therefore in the same terms as when originally drafted. . .

He then particularly castigates statements made by the then Treasurer, now Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in April 1991 when he said that the national wage decision made at that time had been made by just five officials and that the accord was the primary national income determining institution, not the Commission. He then goes on finally to castigate the relationship that exists between the Secretary of the ACTU and the Prime Minister. He has this to say—and these words are very redolent of charges that have been levied by us against the Government since 1983:
The so called Accord process has been manipulated to such an extent that it is only the Prime Minister and the Secretary of the ACTU who are now involved in its decision making procedures.

Here we have a man who has been in the Labor Party for 40 years saying that the industrial relations of this country are run exclusively by the Secretary of the ACTU and the Prime Minister. Yet no doubt in the lead-up to the next election as those opposite go around the country, as they undoubtedly will, trying to impugn the integrity of the Opposition's proposals on industrial relations, they will seek to resurrect the role of the Industrial Relations Commission. They will seek to say to the Australian public that the Industrial Relations Commission stands between decency and the Australian way and the marauding changes that are proposed by the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: The supreme irony of that attempt will be the fact that it has been the Labor Party, the ACTU and, in particular, the present Prime Minister, who have done more in their covert, seditious way to undermine the role of the Industrial Relations Commission than any other group of people in this country. I have never disguised my desire to reduce the role of the Industrial Relations Commission in the industrial relations affairs of this country. I believe, and have believed for many years, that what this nation needs is an industrial relations system that elevates the direct contract between the employer and the employee above all other industrial arrangements. I believe we need in this country an industrial arrangement which essentially says to people, `You go and make your own arrangements and, provided you observe certain prescribed minima regarding hourly rates of pay, regarding such things as annual leave, sick leave, health and public safety requirements, you ought to be free to make any arrangement you choose'.

If we can reach in this country an industrial relations system that is based upon that approach, we have a genuine hope of enjoying the productivity break-out and the productivity benefits that we all know are there to be had if only we can deliver to Australian employers and employees the industrial relations system that will bring forth the productivity benefits to inspire the Australian people.

The Labor Party will try to resurrect the role of the Industrial Relations Commission, but it will endeavour to do so in vain. The Government decided in April last year to torpedo the national wage decision. When the Secretary of the ACTU returned from a union conference in Europe immediately after that decision was brought down, he rang up his mate, the then Treasurer, and said, `We have got to defy this decision'. Ever since then, the two of them conspired to defy that decision and to undermine the position of the former Prime Minister, whose mind was on other things—I think it was gold. A certain luncheon had received a great deal of notoriety; that luncheon involved raising money for the 1987 election campaign.

I think we all remember that the former Prime Minister's attention was a little bit diverted. He was a little worried about what his mates over in Perth had been doing at that luncheon in 1987 and his mind was not fully on the industrial relations game. If it had been on the industrial relations game, there is no way that he would have allowed the government that he then led to torpedo a decision of the Industrial Relations Commission. He would have known, if his mind had been well and truly on the game, that to allow that to happen would be to reduce the authority of the Industrial Relations Commission and to kneecap the strongest participant in the Government's industrial relations argument. It would have been, in his eyes, the soccer equivalent of `kicking an own goal'.

The former Prime Minister would have understood the mistake that was made by the Government if his mind had been fully attuned to that particular issue; but, of course, it was not. It was possible for the Secretary of the ACTU and the then Treasurer to bring about a torpedoing of that particular decision of the Industrial Relations Commission. From that day onward, the authority of the Industrial Relations Commission in Australia was permanently reduced. There is nothing that those opposite can do between now and the next election to resurrect the authority of the Industrial Relations Commission. They can try as much as they like. They can say how much they believe in an impartial commission. I can tell those opposite that the Commission does not believe in them any more. The Commission is in open revolt against the Government.

I predict that before another four or five months elapses there will be further resignations from the Industrial Relations Commission. Some of those resignations will cause greater embarrassment to the Government than the resignation of Mr Turbet, to which I referred earlier in my remarks. It is one thing to be confronted by an alternative government that says, quite openly, `We believe that your role is too big. We believe that your role ought to be reduced. We believe that, rather than you having the lion's share of determining wages and conditions in Australia they ought to be determined by contract'; it is an entirely different thing for an incumbent government to say, `Of course, we think you are the pinnacle. We think you are the umpire, the keeper of the ring, the arbiter of fair play', and all those things, and then spend most of its time trying to badmouth the members of the Commission. Anybody who knows anything about industrial relations knows that the personal relations between senior people in the ACTU and the members of the Commission over the past few months have deteriorated to an all-time low.

We are open about our intentions. I have had discussions with the President of the Industrial Relations Commission, who is realistic enough to acknowledge that, come a change of government, life will be very different and the Commission will have a much diminished role. But his attitude, quite properly, is that if the Parliament of Australia changes the law and gives the Commission a different role, it will cop it because that is how it operates in a democracy. But those opposite, in typically hypocritical fashion, say, `We love the Industrial Relations Commission. We want it to control everything'. Then they go about transferring the authority of the Industrial Relations Commission away from it into the hands of Bill Kelty and the Prime Minister.

A duumvirate runs Australia's industrial relations now. Most Australians are aware of it. Of course, it has been the words and the remarks of a Labor man of 40 years standing who has blown the whistle in a very effective and a very disabling way on the tactics that the Labor Party, and the Government generally, has adopted on this issue.

Reforming Australia's industrial relations system is undeniably the major economic reform that this country needs. That is a view that I have adhered to for many years. It is a view that is strongly shared and supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Despite all of the attempts that are being made by the Government to paint the industrial relations program of the Opposition as being extreme, radical and insensitive to Australian workers, the truth of the matter is that the accord process has failed the most important test. The most important test is productivity. Those opposite can grimace and guffaw and carry on as much as they like, but if they look at the OECD examinations of the performance of the Australian economy, if they look at any objective analysis of the performance of the Australian economy, they will find that over the last few years the one thing that we undeniably come last in is productivity performance.

Of course, those opposite created 1 1/2 million jobs through the 1980s, but they created them at $70,000 a head. Any fool can create 1 1/2 million jobs if he is prepared to escalate Australia's overseas debt from $21 billion to $145 billion. When I stopped being Treasurer of Australia in 1983, this country owed the rest of the world $21 billion. The latest count has it at $145 billion. Those opposite think that is a good performance. What is their reply? Their reply is that they created 1 1/2 million jobs. They created 1 1/2 million jobs at a cost of $70,000 a head. That is no achievement; that is no performance; and that is no record that any group of men and women ought to be proud of.
Mr Lavarch interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the honourable member now interjects. Is he going to tell me it was $75,000 a job? The fact of the matter is that those opposite went hopelessly into debt in order to create an artificial boom. That artificial boom has delivered this country the worst recession it has had for 60 years. Everybody is now paying for it, yet those opposite regard that as a monumental economic achievement.

PARA.TAB: The OECD, time and time again, blows the whistle on the Government's accord. Time and time again it points out that the great casualty of the accord in Australia has been appallingly low productivity. The only way in which over the next few years we can climb out of the enormous international debt level that the Prime Minister more than any other person in Australia is responsible for—it is the Prime Minister's debt, although it is a debt that the Australian public has to bear—is to dramatically lift our productivity performance.

As I think even those opposite would acknowledge, national productivity does not exist in a vacuum; national productivity is the sum total of the productivity of individual firms around this country. It is our view that the only way we can achieve the productivity break-out that Australia needs is to have an industrial relations system that is focused exclusively on the enterprise.

Those opposite would have us believe that they are interested in enterprise bargaining. They would have us believe in their form of Claytons enterprise bargaining, where nothing can be agreed unless the union says yes and the Industrial Relations Commission says yes. That is their enterprise bargaining. There is one thing that members of the Labor Party will never do when it comes to enterprise bargaining: they will never actually let the enterprise bargain.

I have the details of an example in my drawer. It is an example that ought to be emblazoned on the minds of every member of this House. A company employing 500 people went to its work force towards Christmas of 1990 and said, `Look, we are in a hopeless financial position. We are going to effect the following economies with management. Will you, as a work force, make a contribution and agree to the deferral of the 17.5 per cent holiday loading this Christmas on the understanding that if we trade into the black next year, you can not only have the 17.5 per cent, you can also have 25 per cent holiday loading for the following Christmas'. There was a ballot amongst the 500 employees—none of whom, incidentally, belonged to a union—and they voted overwhelmingly to accept the company's offer.

So they trotted off to the Industrial Relations Commission, and the Industrial Relations Commission said, `We can't vary the award'. As those opposite would know, such an agreement constituted an award variation. Under the present pre-World War I industrial laws of Australia, which are supported and embraced by this present Government, what did the Industrial Relations Commission do? It said, `We can't vary that without getting a request from the union, because the union is a respondent to the award'. So, reluctantly, because the law required it the company went off to the relevant union, to which none of the employees by their own decision wanted to belong, and said, `On our behalf, would you please make an application for variation of the award?'. The union in effect said, `Get lost. We are not interested'.

So the company went back to its employees and said, `We are very sorry, we can't give effect to this agreement, because we can't get an award variation. We are not prepared to put the agreement into effect because we could get prosecuted for a breach of the award.' It is pretty obvious what happened—the company retrenched a number of its employees early the following year. That is Australian industrial relations; that is how much flexibility there is in Australian industrial relations; that is how much enterprise bargaining there is in Australia at present under the laws that those opposite would have us support.

It does pass very strange to me, that the Government, whose leader has spent an inordinate amount of time over the last few weeks castigating those on this side of the House for their regard for certain historical attitudes and values in this country, should cling with such tenacity, as he so obviously does, to an industrial relations system which owes its origins to pre-World War I Australia. If ever there were an anachronistic institution, if ever there were a set of attitudes and values of the past which ought to be thrown out, it is our attitude towards industrial relations.

I do not think we should ever adopt a blindly radical or a blindly conservative attitude towards past attitudes and practice. I have always been something of a selective conservative. I think we ought to hang on to those things from the past that work well, and I think we ought to throw out those things from the past that do not work very well.

In relation to another pastime of the Prime Minister's, could I also say that I think we ought to hang onto those things we have inherited from the United Kingdom that work very well, such as our existing system of constitutional government with all of its checks and balances. I think we ought to throw out those things that we inherited from the United Kingdom that have not worked very well, such as some of our stupid trade union attitudes. We could well do without some of the attitudes that we have inherited from the United Kingdom in the industrial relations area.

It is very strange that the Labor Party wants to throw out the good things that we inherited from the United Kingdom, but it wants to hang on tenaciously to the bad things. It wants to hang on to many of the old craft union attitudes; the `them and us' attitudes. It still talks about class struggle; it still talks in terms of nineteenth century Europe and struggles between classes in countries in Europe and in the United Kingdom. It is a very strange double standard. It picks on the good things that we have inherited to throw out, but it wants to hang on to the bad things. I say to my colleagues opposite, `Why do you not get rid of the trade union cultural cringe that you have inherited from the United Kingdom? Why do you not get rid of some of those stupid attitudes that have done that country enormous damage'?

The double irony is that sensible people in that country have thrown out those attitudes years ago. That is one of the reasons why the Government's soul brothers over there suffered such a searing defeat a few weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on; that is a bit of an exaggeration.

—We have got the honourable member for Throsby interrupting. The Labour Party was absolutely thumped. Those opposite all thought that their mate Kinnock was going to get up, and he was done like a dinner. The reason he was done like a dinner is that Margaret Thatcher has brought about a permanent change of attitude in the United Kingdom. Those opposite do not like it, but it happens to be true. The honourable member for Throsby ought to know better than many in the House.
—Why the honourable member for Throsby?

—He is a very knowledgable man, and I am always prepared to pay due deference to somebody who is versatile in the political ways of the world. The truth of the matter is that this Bill represents yet another example of this Government's capacity to do the bidding of the ACTU. Even the most charitable and the most benign commentator on the industrial relations policy of the Government would have to acknowledge that this long running fight between the Industrial Relations Commission and the ACTU has been unedifying. It has been spiteful, it has been personal, it has been abusive, it has led to a collapse in relations between the ACTU and the members of the Commission, and it has led to an unprecedented level of hostility.

PARA.TAB: One has to be a pretty clever industrial relations Minister and a pretty clever Labor Government to produce a situation whereby a government that is pledged to support, in theory, the role of the Industrial Relations Commission, actually finds itself more reviled and detested by the members of the Industrial Relations Commission and the industrial relations establishment than the other side of politics which quite openly and honestly says, `We have nothing against you personally, but we just want to reduce your role; we want to alter your role; we want to reduce the emphasis on arbitrated awards; we want to write an industrial relations law that provides employers and employees with an incentive to go outside the system'.

For those reasons, and also because it is nearing 10.30 p.m. and I think that might well be an appropriate time for the debate to be interrupted, I conclude my remarks by saying again that the Opposition will vote against this legislation. It represents yet another of the many milestones along the hard march of the Labor Party towards a complete surrender of industrial relations to the mandarins of the ACTU. When it comes to industrial relations under this Government, it is yet another illustration of the fact that when Bob Hawke was President of the ACTU he said of Bill Kelty that he was the sorcerer's apprentice. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this adjournment debate to remind those members of this House who need reminding, notably the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), not only of the historical and traditional ties between Australia and the country he seems to love to hate—namely, Britain—but also of the strong economic ties which exist between the two and which may well be endangered by his racist remarks. Note the word `racist'. The Prime Minister himself not so long ago launched an attack on racist attitudes in Australia, and quite rightly so. Yet the chronic Anglophobia revealed recently in his assault on the monarchy, the flag and other things reflecting our British heritage must surely constitute a racist attitude against the largest ethnic group in Australia, namely, the Anglo-Celts, who also happen to be descendants of this nation's founding fathers.
—Order! The honourable member for La Trobe will pay the member on his feet the courtesy of not walking between him and the Chair.

—However, in this speech, I will deal primarily with the economic relationship between Australia and Britain and particularly with British investment in Australia. On 30 March 1992, figures obtained from the Overseas Trade Services Department of the British High Commission in Canberra cited over 700 UK companies and/or their subsidiaries established in Australia. Accurate figures as to the actual work force involved are unobtainable, but some projects are large and would require considerable manpower. Examples would be William Press and Cape PLG in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: As to investment, in December 1991, the UK was the third highest investor in Australia at $48,076m, being surpassed only narrowly by Japan at $51,030m and the United States at $53,922m. To be more specific, in 1990—the latest date for available figures—the UK was the highest investor in manufacturing with $14,950m being invested, compared with the United States at $13,577m and Japan at $4,124m. In mining, the UK was the second highest investor at $4,515m, compared with the United States at $10,221m. In finance, property and business services, Japan led investment with $18,098m, compared with Britain's $11,884m.
Recently in Perth, the British High Commissioner, Sir Brian Barder, made reference to the economic relationship between Britain and Australia. I quote from his comments on that occasion:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Britain's position in Europe and Australia's position in the Asia Pacific give both countries new opportunities to strengthen our mutual relationship. Each of our countries can give the other opportunities it would not otherwise have. A growing number of British firms see the value of having a base in Australia to get into Asian markets . . . The flow of Australian investment to Britain shows clearly that many Australian firms see Britain as their best base for European operations.

Sir Brian went on to give numerous examples of Australia-Britain cooperation in business ventures. For example, in the defence field, GEC Marconi has signed a contract with Australian Telecom for the design and supply of an advanced radar network for the defence of Australia; the value is over $250m.

PARA.TAB: It seems most unfortunate, in view of the evidence of cooperation and mutual interest between Australia and Britain, that Prime Minister Keating should display such a blatantly hostile attitude to one of our most important trading partners. The Prime Minister's insulting demeanour towards Britain has been widely reported in the media of that country, as it has been here. Although some might assert that business is business and the public relationship between the two countries will make little difference, it should also be pointed out that, privately, insults are hard to forget. It would be a tragedy if the sound business relationship between Britain and Australia was to be jeopardised by, of all people, our own Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: The social and economic impact on the Illawarra region has been drastic not only for the jobs lost in the steel industry but also for the many supporting small enterprises. I was overruled, in a manner which to this day I am angry about, and one day I will tell the full story. This was $19m allocated for work in the Illawarra, for projects of benefit to the Illawarra, but taken from the Illawarra.

Last Thursday, the New South Wales State Premier announced the sale of the New South Wales Grain Corporation for some $90m. The facility at Port Kembla itself cost many millions more than this to build. —He initially came to us with a One Nation statement promoting unity. Clearly, he is no longer interested in unity; he prefers to provoke disunity. There is no national unity to be created in attempting to denigrate the Australian flag which has been loved by Australians for many generations.

—Others have also played an important part, if the Parliamentary Secretary would care to listen. It is ironic that those on the other side of the House have attacked organised labour through the Bills that have been introduced over the past 12 months. Those in the National Party, who are agrarian socialists, want to maintain the various structures of regulations but do not want working men and women to have the right to organise and sell their labour in a cohesive manner with central wage fixation. There is the argument about how great voluntary agreements are and the freedom and the rights of individuals to argue against corporations. I think that is a tragedy. That is certainly not the road that Australia should follow. As we celebrate Labour Day today in Queensland, one great thing is that we will never reach that situation, provided we have a strong and viable trade union movement and a belief in social justice. ANL has entered a joint venture with the CSIRO to develop in Australia a brand new packaging concept, which the CSIRO has developed, which will transform the face of fresh produce marketing and the delivery of Australian produce. We were informed of a test that was done. A truckload of fresh flowers was picked in Perth and transported by road across to Melbourne wrapped in this packaging, and it took a week. Then it was put on a ship and delivered to Tokyo. It was opened six weeks after going into the container. After a transport cycle of seven weeks, the flowers looked as though they had been picked yesterday. That is totally an Australian invention; it is a CSIRO invention. It is great that the ANL put up the capital to develop it.

I will have to hurry along, and hurry along we did. We hurried over to the South Dynon Rail Terminal where we saw that trucks now unload their containers in an average time of 12 minutes, not the three to six hours that is conveyed out in the countryside by our Opposition. Twelve minutes is the average time in Melbourne now for a truck to unload or collect a container at the railway yard. Then we went over to Webb Dock where we saw the latest in container shipping. Again, how long does a truck stay at the wharf? In common mythology, it takes anywhere between two and three days; in fact, it takes half an hour to three hours. That is the mythology that we have to get on with dispelling. That was the point of this exercise. Then we went to East Swanson Dock to have a look at the same thing there.

I did have with me as guests over 50 public opinion leaders from around the western and northern sections of Melbourne, from the Geelong Standard Rail Committee, the Goulburn Valley producers and up the Calder Highway to Mildura councillors. I worked out that those people between them represent one million Victorians. All I can say is that their minds were blown to see the fact as against the mythology.

The final thing I want to say is that I publicly issue an invitation to the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), who is at the table on the Opposition side—he is a gentleman that I like and have regard for—to join me on the next one of these visits. If he were ever to become the Land Transport Minister, I would want him to continue these good works that are being done by our Labor Government for people. It demonstrates our commitment to public sector operations and our commitment to making the transport sector reforms work.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the remaining few seconds of the adjournment debate, I would like to represent the city of Wanneroo, which is the largest municipality in my electorate and the second fastest growing municipality in Australia. It is an area of great growth and great development. But, unfortunately, it has the problem with undetected, unexploded ordnance that has been deposited and landed in the area since exercises were conducted before and during the Second World War.

PARA.TAB: For some time now, the city has been negotiating with the Federal Government to try to get the Federal Government to assist with the detection and the removal of unexploded ordnance within sections of the city of Wanneroo. Unfortunately, the Federal Government has refused to accept liability for the cost of detection and removal of these items which can, of course, pose a danger to the users of the land, whether it be for development use or purely for recreational use.

On behalf of the ratepayers of the city of Wanneroo and my constituents, I urge the Federal Government to reconsider its opposition to funding the detection and the removal of this unexploded ordnance that remains there from those exercises from the Second World War.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 30 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to (a) allegations made on the television program `A Current Affair` on 25 March 1992 that a Newcastle medical practitioner was prescribing anabolic steroids to 200 body builders and (b) evidence referred to in the second report of the inquiry into drugs in sport conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts that a pharmacist filled more than 1000 anabolic steroid prescriptions for a medical practitioner during a seven month period.
(2) Is he able to say what is the cost to the health care system of the prescription of anabolic steroids to body builders and others for reasons other than the treatment of genuine medical ailments.

(3) Is he also able to say what is the cost to the health care system resulting from medical practitioners ordering various tests, including pathology tests, to attempt to monitor the adverse health effects on their patients that may result from the misuse of anabolic steroids.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No, I am not aware of the specific allegations made on the television program `A Current Affair` on 25 March 1992 that a Newcastle medical practitioner was prescribing anabolic steroids to 200 body builders.

However, I am aware of evidence referred to in the second report of the inquiry into drugs in sport conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts that a pharmacist filled more than 1000 anabolic steroid prescriptions for a medical practitioner during a seven month period.

The Senate Standing Committee was of the view that the Medical Board of Queensland is the appropriate body to consider the medical practitioner's conduct and to decide if breaches have occurred sufficient to justify deregistration (p283).

The Committee also considered the pharmacist was in breach of pharmacists' professional standards and of a statement provided by the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia to the Committee regarding the supply of performance modifying drugs to athletes (p320). Accordingly, the State Pharmacy Board of Queensland would be the appropriate body to consider the pharmacist's conduct and to decide if breaches have occurred sufficient to justify deregistration. Again this is a State matter, not a Commonwealth one.
It should be noted that the Senate Committee found that over half the anabolic steroids sold in this seven month period in 1988-89 were for veterinary use (p312). The ethical issue of using

ANSWER.PARA: drugs for veterinary purposes for humans is again a State matter, and should be dealt with by the respective Medical and Pharmacy Boards.

PARA.TAB: (2) All the androgenic/anabolic steroids listed on the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits are used for definite medical conditions. Additional restrictions have been placed upon the prescribing of each of these drugs to indicate to the doctor the specific medical conditions for which they can be used.
On the basis that medical practitioners prescribe in accordance with the listed indications, the cost to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme for `body building' should therefore be nil.
The androgenic/anabolic steroids listed on the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits include:
Fluoxymesterone
Methenolone Acetate
Nandrolone Decanoate
Nandrolone Phenylpropionate
Oxymetholone
Testosterone Enanthate
Testosterone Esters
Testosterone Undecanoate

ANSWER.PARA: (Methyltestosterone was deleted from the Schedule on 1 April 1992.)

PARA.TAB: None of these drugs listed on the Schedule is available for `body building'.

164,197 prescriptions for these drugs were dispensed in 1991 for a total cost to the Scheme of $2,222,981. If prescriptions were written for illegal use, the Health Insurance Commission has no way of identifying these.

(3) It is not possible to determine if there is a cost to Medicare resulting from medical practitioners treating adverse health effects from the misuse of anabolic steroids. The public quite rightly do not have to produce records of their ailments or clinical notes when availing themselves of their entitlements to Medicare benefits.

At the same time, if practitioners are `screening' their patients to monitor any adverse health effects through the misuse of anabolic steroids and those `screening' tests are charged against Medicare, the Health Insurance Act 1973 is being breached. The Health Insurance Commission has procedures to monitor and to counsel those offending practitioners.
